﻿THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF HARALSON COUNTY, GEORGIA ____________ Published in 2009 by Order of the Board of Commissioners ____________
OFFICIALS of HARALSON COUNTY, GEORGIA AT THE TIME OF THIS CODIFICATION ____________ H. Allen Poole Chairman/CEO, Board of Commissioners ____________ Eric Robinson, District 1 Bob Birky, District 2 Vance Posey, District 3 Sammy Robinson, District 4 Board of Commissioners ____________ Meng Lim County Attorney ____________ Alison Palmer County Clerk PREFACE

PREFACE This Code constitutes a codification of the general and permanent ordinances of Haralson County, Georgia. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were ordinances adopted by the board of commissioners through November 20, 2007. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any ordinance included herein. The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. Chapter and Section Numbering System The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. Page Numbering System The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes:
Index The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. Looseleaf Supplements A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. Acknowledgments This publication was under the direct supervision of Sandra S. Fox, Code Attorney, and Howard George, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. The publisher is most grateful to Allen Poole, Chairman of the Board of Commissioners; Allison Palmer, County Administrator; Ming Lim, County Attorney; Bryan Walker, Fire Chief; Mike Pope, Animal Control Director; Michael Parker, Emergency Management Agency Director; and Glenda Wade, Zoning Administrative Assistant for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the county readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the county's affairs. Copyright All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and Haralson County, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and Haralson County, Georgia. © Copyrighted material. Municipal Code Corporation and Haralson County, Georgia. 2009. Haralson County Board of Commissioners H. Allen Poole Chairman/C.E.O. AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR HARALSON COUNTY, GEORGIA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. BE IT ORDAINED BY THE HARALSON COUNTY BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS Section 1. The Code entitled "The Code of Ordinances of Haralson County, Georgia," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 50, each inclusive, is adopted. Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before November 4, 2008, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 and imprisonment for a term of not greater than 90 days. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the county may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the county to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. Section 6. Ordinances adopted after November 4, 2008, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective May 20, 2009 Passed and adopted by the HCBOC this 20 th day of May 20 , 2009 . ;sigr; H. Allen Poole \Chairman ATTEST:

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.
CODE OF ORDINANCES

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The provisions embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of Ordinances of Haralson County, Georgia," and may be so cited. This Code may also be referred to by the shortened form, "Haralson County Code." State Law reference— Authority to adopt ordinances for regulation of matters for which no provision has been made by general law, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20; duty to codify ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. As used in this Code, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings indicated unless otherwise specifically provided, and the following rules of construction shall be applied: Applicability. In the construction of this Code, and of all the ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of commissioners. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which contain any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of the section may be repugnant thereto. As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. Board of commissioners. The term "board of commissioners" means the governing authority of Haralson County, Georgia. Code. The term "Code" refers to The Code of Ordinances of Haralson County, Georgia. Computation of time. When a number of days is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, only the first day shall not be counted, but the last day shall be counted. If the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following business day to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, an intermediate Saturday, Sunday, and legal holiday shall be excluded in the computation. Conjunctions. Where the provisions involves two or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by any of the conjunctions "and," "or," "either . . . or," or "neither . . . nor," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows; provided, that in the appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: (1) The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. (2) The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events may apply singly or in any combination. (3) The terms "either . . . or" and "neither . . . nor" indicate that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. County . The term "the county" or "this county" means Haralson County, Georgia. Court. The term "court" means the county court. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or other officer of the county to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. Department; board; agency. The name or title of any department, board, or agency, unless otherwise specifically stated otherwise, shall be read as though the words "of the County of Haralson County, Georgia" were added thereto. Fee schedule or schedule of fees and charges. The term "fee schedule" or "schedule of fees and charges" means the official consolidated list maintained in the county clerk's office that lists rates for utility or other public enterprises, fees of any nature, deposit amounts and various charges as determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. Gender. A word importing, the masculine gender only extends and be implied to female and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. Governing authority, governing body . The term "governing authority" or "governing body" means the board of commissioners of Haralson County, Georgia. Incorporated limits or incorporated areas of the county means all areas of the county that are not situated within the territorial limits of an incorporated town or city. Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than any general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be applicable. Joint authority. Whenever a joint authority is given to three or more persons or officers, it shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of them. Judge. The term "judge" means the judge of the county court. Keeper, proprietor . The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons as the term "person" is defined herein, whether acting by themselves or through an agent or employee. Law. The term "law" means and denotes applicable federal law, the state constitution and statutes, this Code, ordinances and resolutions of the county, and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations that may be promulgated thereunder. Liberal construction; minimum requirements; overlapping provisions. (1) The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. (2) In all interpretations the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the board of commissioners, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil, and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. (3) All general provisions, terms, phrases, and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of commissioners may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare. May . The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. Nontechnical and technical terms. Terms and phrases shall be constructed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical terms and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. Number. The singular number includes the plural and the plural number includes the singular. Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the term "swear" or "sworn." O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." refers to the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Officials or officers. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards commissions, departments or other municipal agents by title only, such reference shall be read as though followed by the term "of Haralson County, Georgia." Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a legislative act of the municipal governing body of a general and permanent nature. Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or to land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, join tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization, and any other group action as a unit, as well as an individual. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as hereinafter defined. Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" means next before and next after, respectively. Premises. Whenever the term "premises" is used it means place or places. Property. The term "property" includes real, personal, and mixed estates and interests. Public place. The term "public place" means any park, cemetery, shopping center, schoolyard, or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or publicly owned, and any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or to congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments. Reasonable time or reasonable notice . Reasonable time or notice means only such time as may be necessary for the prompt performance of the act required. Residence. The term "residence" means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Resolution. The term "resolution" means a legislative act of the county governing authority of a special or temporary character. Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, but shall not include any unimproved area between the curbline and improved walkways. Signature, subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark intended as such when the person cannot write. State. The term "state" or "this state" means the State of Georgia. Statute . The term "statute," unless otherwise specifically stated, refers to the indicated portion of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Street. The term "street" means and includes any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, viaduct or bridge, and the approaches thereto, within the county. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," when applied to a building or to land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Week. The term "week" means seven days. Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. Writing or written. The terms "writing" and "written" include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. State Law reference— Statutory definitions and rules of construction, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq.; construction of statutory definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; general statutory definition, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines, notes, and references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, not as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. (b) The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are intended merely to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes, charter references and state law references that appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. (c) All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions, or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions, or section of this Code, unless otherwise specified. State Law reference— Notes and catch lines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Effect of references to prior Code sections. References in the city forms, documents, citations and regulations to the chapters and sections of this Code shall be constructed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this Code. Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal or expiration of Code section. (a) The repeal of a Code section or ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued or any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred, or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. (b) When any ordinance repealing a Code section, ordinance, clause or provision, shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such Code section, ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided. Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by county personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the board of commissioners or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. Charter amendments may be included in like manner. (b) In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ through ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the a case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the board of commissioners. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of The Code of Ordinances of Haralson County, is hereby amended to read as follows: " ____________ ". The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That The Code of Ordinances of Haralson County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered ____________ , which said section reads as follows: " ____________ ". The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters or provisions to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, with reference to the subject matter, as the case may be. Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to altar or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the board of commissioners. State Law reference— Altering, falsifying, or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-9. - Exclusion of special or temporary ordinances. Ordinances hereafter adopted which are not of a general or permanent nature shall be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof. Sec. 1-10. - Form of Code; repository; maintenance. A copy of this Code shall be kept on file in the office of the county clerk, preserved in loose-leaf form, or in such other form as the clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the clerk or his designee to insert in their designated places all resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances that indicate the intention of the board of commissioners to make the same a part of this Code, when the same have been printed or reprinted in a page form, and to extract from this Code all provisions that may be from time to time repealed by the board of commissioners. A copy of this Code shall be available in the office of the county clerk for examination by all persons. State Law reference— Inspection of public records, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq.; requirements for publication of code, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-11. - Responsibility of county personnel with respect to assigned copies of Code. Each county official or employee assigned a copy of this Code shall be responsible for maintaining the same and for the proper insertion of amendatory pages as received. Each such copy shall remain the property of the county and shall be turned over by the official or employee having custody thereof, upon expiration of his term of office or employment, to his successor or to the county clerk, in case he shall have no successor. Sec. 1-12. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. Sec. 1-13. - General penalty: continuing violations, violations as public nuisance. (a) In this section, the phrase "violation of this Code" means: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared to be an unlawful act, an offense, or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by a rule or a regulation authorized by the ordinance; (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by an ordinance, a rule, or a regulation authorized by the ordinance; or (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor, an offense, or an unlawful omission by an ordinance, a rule, or a regulation authorized by the ordinance. (b) The phrase "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a county officer or county employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context of this Code that it is the intent of the county to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the county officer or employee. (c) Except as otherwise provided in this Code a person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days or community service, including, but not limited to, work on the streets or public works, for a period not exceeding 90 days, or both, or any combination thereof. (d) All sentences must be in the alternative, and fines may be imposed with the alternative of the other punishment in the event the fines are not paid. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense. (e) Any community service imposed as a penalty must be performed within one year from the date of conviction, unless a shorter period is ordered by the court. Any person placed on community service, or otherwise placed on probation, for violation of this Code shall pay such supervisory fees as may be authorized by law. (f) Except as otherwise provided in this Code, each day that a violation of this Code continues shall constitute a separate offense. (g) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. Further, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rules, regulation or order shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the county as provided by law. (h) The imposition of a penalty does not prohibit equitable relief. (i) The imposition of a penalty does not prohibit revocation or suspension of a license, permit, or franchise or the imposition of other administrative sanctions. (j) All fines shall be paid into the county treasury. (k) In the event community service is substituted for a fine, the monetary rate for hourly work shall be the federal minimum hourly wage. (l) If it is deemed by a court of competent jurisdiction that a punishment imposed under this Code conflicts with the laws of the state, the punishment shall be the maximum permitted by law. State Law reference— Maximum penalties that may be imposed by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-32-1, 36-32-5; additional penalties and bond in certain criminal and traffic cases, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; authority to impose community service as punishment, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-1; alternative sentences by municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-5. Sec. 1-14. - Additional penalties for funding county correctional facilities. (a) In every case in which any court in this county shall impose a fine, which shall be construed to include costs, for any offense against a criminal or traffic law of this state or any offense against a county ordinance, there shall be imposed as an additional penalty, a sum equal to ten percent of the original fine. (b) At the time of posting bail or bond in any case involving a violation of a criminal or traffic law of this state or a violation of a county ordinance, an additional sum equal to ten percent of the original bail or bond shall be posted. In every case in which any court in this county shall order the forfeiture of bail or bond, the additional sum equal to ten percent of the original bail or bond shall be collected. (c) The additional penalties set forth in subsection (b) of this section shall be in addition to that amount required by O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60, to be paid into the peace officers' annuity and benefit fund, by O.C.G.A. § 47-11-51, to be paid into the judges of the probate court retirement fund of the state, or by any other provision of law. (d) The additional penalties as herein prescribed shall be assessed and collected by the clerk or court officer charged with the duty of collecting monies arising from fines and forfeited bonds. Such additional penalties shall be paid over to the board of commissioners by the tenth day of the month following the month in which these sums are collected. All such sums collected and paid over to the board of commissioners shall be deposited into a special account which shall be known as the "county jail fund." (e) All monies collected pursuant to this section and placed in the county jail fund shall be expended solely and exclusively for constructing, operating, and staffing the county correctional facilities, or for such other purposes as specified in O.C.G.A. § 15-21-95. (f) The additional penalties provided for by this section shall not be imposed or collected in any court operated by any municipality located in the county. (Res. of 5-5-1992) Sec. 1-15. - Drug penalties to be shared with state attorney fund. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-13-49(u)(4)(B), the county hereby authorizes ten percent of all monies distributed as a result of drug forfeiture cases handled by the district attorney's office to be set aside in a special expense account for use by the district attorney. As provided by said law, this money shall be in addition to any other expenses paid by the county to the district attorney's office. (Res. of 10-6-1992) Sec. 1-16. - Continuation of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are substantially the same as ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-17. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any rates, fees or charges consistent with this Code; (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the county; (3) Any ordinance or resolution consistent with this Code prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; (4) Any ordinance or resolution consistent with this Code fixing salaries of, or providing policies and programs for, providing retirement, disability or death benefits for, officials, officers or employees of the county; (5) Any budget ordinance or appropriation ordinance; (6) Any ordinance levying any tax; (7) Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution; (8) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the county; (9) Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the county; (10) Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; (11) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision within the county; (12) Any zoning ordinance or any ordinance regulating subdivisions or any ordinance regulating signs or any ordinance regulating building design standards; (13) Any ordinance or resolution adopted for purposes that have been consummated; (14) Any ordinance that is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; and (15) Any resolution of the county not in conflict with this Code. (b) All such ordinances or resolutions are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Sec. 1-18. - Exclusion of special or temporary ordinances. Ordinances, hereafter adopted, which are not of a general or permanent nature shall be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof. Sec. 1-19. - Severability of parts of Code. If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, it shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of this Code. State Law reference— Severability of state legislation, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. Sec. 1-20. - Conflicting regulations. (a) If the provisions of different chapters conflict with each other, the provisions of each individual chapter shall control all issues arising out of the events and persons intended to be governed by that chapter. (b) If the provisions of different sections of the same chapter conflict with each other, the provision which is more specific in its application to the events or persons raising the conflict shall control over the more general provision. (c) If any of the provisions hereof conflict, and the conflict cannot be resolved by application of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the more stringent regulation shall apply and the specific provision shall prevail over the general. Sec. 1-21. - Fee schedule; fees established by resolution. The county maintains a schedule of fees for permits, licenses, and other county charges. The amount of fees or charges imposed by the county including, but not limited to, those encompassed in the county's fee schedule, shall be established from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners, as it deems necessary and appropriate. The county's schedule of fees as printed in appendix A to this Code is available for inspection in the office of the county clerk.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; regulation of alcoholic beverages generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1 et seq.; authority of local authorities to license and regulate alcoholic beverage sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; local regulation of sales on Sundays, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; prohibited acts on licensed premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-40 et seq.; malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-1 et seq.; wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-1 et seq.; local licensing requirements for sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; requirements for sale of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, malt beverage, malt beverage, wine, or fortified wine as defined in this section. Applicant means any one or more persons applying for a county license or renewal thereof. Application means those forms required by the county to be completed by persons applying for an original license or a renewal license under this chapter. Beer means "malt beverage" as that term is defined herein. Church means any place of permanent public religious worship and shall exist if a building permit therefore has been obtained and construction of the church building has commenced or substantial materials or supplies for its construction have been moved to the site where it is to be built. Convicted includes an adjudication of guilt on a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime. Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. Employed on the licensed premises and work on any licensed premises mean work done or services performed on the physical location of the licensed premises as well as work done or services performed while in the scope of employment elsewhere than on the licensed premises. License means the formal approval granted or issued by the county to a licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages within the county. Licensee means the individual or business entity to which the license is issued. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion of decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product or any combination of the products in water, containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager, malt beverage, small malt beverage, and strong malt beverage. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Minor means any person under the age of 21 years. Parcel of land means any quantity of land capable of being described by location and boundary, designated and used or to be used as a unit. Premises means, not only the structure wherein any premises for sale of alcoholic beverages is operated under a county license, but includes all of the lot whereon the premises is located, except where the premises is located in a hotel or shopping center. Prepared food means any food item or meal that is assembled, created, or cooked by a chef or cooks in a full service kitchen on the premises and served to the customer who customarily eats it with eating utensils. Pre-packaged food items (hot or cold) are not recognized as prepared meals because they are not made or assembled on premises. Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised, and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly prepared and served, without sleeping accommodations; the place seating a minimum of 50 people and holding a certificate of approval from the county health department. Stools for serving at a counter or bar shall not be considered as seating facilities as contemplated herein. Wholesaler or wholesale dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail dealers, or retail consumption dealers. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by fermentation or natural fermentation with brandy added. Wine includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of the beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Secs. 4-2—4-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-21. - Privilege; revocation. The sale of alcoholic beverages with the county is a mere privilege and not a right, and the county board of commissioners reserves the right to limit the total number of license issues and to revoke the license of any wholesale or retail dealer at any time, with or without cause, with or without notice, and notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1. Sec. 4-22. - License classification. The county issues, subject to the limitations and regulations of, and upon the conditions set forth in this article, the following alcoholic beverage licenses: (1) Class A licenses, which authorize the retail sale of malt beverages only for consumption off the premises; (2) Class B licenses, which authorize the retail sale of wine only for consumption off the premises; (3) Class C licenses, which authorize the retail package sales of distilled liquor only for consumption off the premises; (4) Class D licenses, which authorize the retail sale of beer for consumption on the premises; (5) Class E licenses, which authorize the retail sale of wine for consumption on the premises; (6) Class F licenses, which authorize the retail sale of distilled liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises; (7) Class T licenses, which authorize the temporary sale of malt beverages, wine, distilled liquor, or any combination thereof, as specified in the permit; and (8) Class W licenses, which authorize the wholesale sale of alcoholic beverages. Sec. 4-23. - Limitations on total number of licenses issued. The total number of licenses within each class that may be operative simultaneously may be limited by the board of commissioners. Should there be a sufficient number of current licenses to meet the needs and desires of the inhabitants of the county, no new licenses shall be issues. In determining the needs and desires of the inhabitants, the county commissioners shall consider the best interests of the county's citizens, based on factors affecting the local peace, health, and welfare. Secs. 4-24—4-49. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE APPLICATION PROCEDURE[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dealing in malt beverages at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40; county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-41; restriction on county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43; dealing in wine at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-40.
Sec. 4-50. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverages where such person does not have a license from the county to sell or possess such beverages for sale. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VI; Res. of 5-3-1988, § V) Sec. 4-51. - State license required for wholesale licenses. Wholesale licenses shall be issued only to those parties who are licensed by the state to sell and distribute alcoholic beverages at wholesale. Application shall be made with the county clerk. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § III; Res. of 5-3-1988, § II) Sec. 4-52. - Authority to issue licenses. All applications for licenses shall be presented to the board of county commissioners for approval and, if approved, the licenses shall be issued by the county clerk upon the payment of the required fee. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § X; Res. of 5-3-1988, § IX) Sec. 4-53. - Licensee qualifications. (a) An applicant for licensure under this article must be a person of good moral character, a citizen of the United States, and a resident of the county for a period of one year next preceding the date of filing application. This shall not apply to the honorably discharged members of the federal armed forces who have returned to the county within the prescribed limit. (b) The licensee shall not have been convicted within two years of the date of his application of any felony or any violation of the laws of this state, or any other state, relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, or convicted in any federal or state court of a felony, misdemeanor, or other offense involving moral turpitude. (c) The licensee shall be responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. (d) The applicant must be at least 21 years of age. (e) The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to subsections (a) through (d) of this section and shall place same on file with the county clerk before any license is issued. (f) If the application covers a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. (g) No person shall be granted a license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the board of county commissioners that such person shall meet the qualifications of this section. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § III; Res. of 5-3-1988, § II) State Law reference— Discretion and due process regarding grant or suspension of local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 4-54. - Applications for licenses. (a) An applicant for license to sell alcoholic beverages shall file a written application with the county clerk. The application shall contain such information as may be required by the board of commissioners in order to enforce the provisions of this article. (b) The applicant shall publish the application in a local newspaper once a week for four consecutive weeks to coincide with the sheriff's investigation as specified in subsection (c) of this section. (c) Before a license is issued, the application shall be referred by the clerk to the county sheriff. All applicants must be photographed, fingerprinted, and registered with the sheriff's department. The sheriff shall make an investigation and report back to the clerk within 30 days the following information: (1) Whether the person has ever been convicted of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude or ever been convicted of violating malt beverage, wine, or liquor laws of any city, county, state, or federal government. (2) Whether the applicant has ever had an alcoholic beverage license revoked for cause. Sec. 4-55. - Additional requirements and restrictions for licenses for consumption on the premises. (a) In addition to all other requirements for licensure as set forth in this article, applicants for licensure for sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises must have, prior to license issuance, a current county license and health department certificate for a restaurant as defined in section 4-1. (b) Additionally, the sale of malt beverage to be consumed on the premises shall be ancillary to the primary business of serving prepared foods. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § IV; Res. of 5-3-1988, § III) Sec. 4-56. - Nontransferability. Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter are not transferable without the consent of the county board of commissioners. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VIII; Res. of 5-3-1988, § VII) Sec. 4-57. - Business license, regulatory, and investigative fees. (a) License fees. The annual license fees for all licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be as established from time to time by the board of commissioners. Renewal applications and license fees, which shall be the same as fees for original issuance, shall be due no later than December 1 of each year. (b) Regulatory fee . In addition, each licensee under this chapter shall pay the regulatory fee as required in chapter 12, article II pertaining to business regulatory fees. (c) Investigative fees. In addition to license fees, every applicant for a license under this chapter shall pay, at the time of making application for original issuance or renewal of the annual license, a nonrefundable investigative fee in the amount established by the board of commissioners, to defray the cost to the county of inspections, fingerprinting, and criminal background investigations. State Law reference— Limitations on local alcohol licensing fees, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43. Sec. 4-58. - Fingerprinting. (a) As a prerequisite to the issuance of any license, the applicant shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints for all persons required to sign the application to be forwarded to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation and to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as specified under state law. (b) Each person required to sign the application for an original license or renewal license authorizes the county or its designated representatives to secure from any state, county, municipal, or federal court, or any sheriff's department or law enforcement agency, the applicant's criminal history and civil history and further authorizes the county, and its officers and employees, to use the information in determining whether an alcoholic beverage license will be issued to the applicant. (c) The applicant, by submitting the application, authorizes the county, and its officers and employees, to use the information in a public hearing if necessary, to determine whether the applicant's license should be issued, denied, voided, cancelled, or revoked. (d) Each applicant waives any rights the applicant may have under state or federal law or statute or court ruling to preclude the county from securing the criminal or civil history from any source and waives any right the applicant may have to preclude the county from using the information publicly in determining whether the license will be issued to the applicant. Sec. 4-59. - Report of county sheriff or his designee; appeal. (a) Once an application, the accompanying documents, and the required investigative and license fees are filed with the county clerk, a copy of the application and all accompanying documents shall be referred to the county sheriff or his designee for purposes of the investigation required pursuant to this article. (b) The county sheriff or his designee shall make a written report regarding the qualifications of the applicant to the board of commissioners. (c) If the report of the county sheriff or his designee is favorable and the board of commissioners finds that the applicant meets all other qualifications provided in this article, then the board of commissioners shall schedule the application for a hearing at the next board of commissioners meeting and shall so inform the applicant before the meeting. (d) The board of commissioners or its designee shall instruct the applicant, with the exception of applicants for wholesale permits, to publish, prior to the meeting, notice in the form herein provided in the official county newspaper of the county, at least once each week for four consecutive weeks, the applicant's intent to secure a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package or by the drink, the exact location of the place of business for which a license is sought, the names and addresses of each owner of the business, and, if the applicant is a corporation, the names and titles of all corporate officers. (e) If the report of the county sheriff or his designee is unfavorable, or if the board of commissioners finds that the applicant fails to meet all of the qualifications provided in this article, then the board of commissioners shall inform the applicant, in writing, that his application has been denied. The notice shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for the denial and shall notify the applicant of his right to appeal as provided in division 3 of this article. Sec. 4-60. - Review of application by board of commissioners. (a) Any application that the board of commissioners determines satisfies all the qualifications outlined in this article, including absence of prohibited criminal activity as disclosed in the report of the county sheriff or his designee, shall be scheduled for review at the next meeting of the board of commissioners. (b) At that meeting, the applicant and any person opposed to the application has the right to present to the board of commissioners any information that the board of commissioners determines is relevant to the licensing decision. (c) In making its determination with regard to approval or denial of the application, the board of commissioners shall look to the public interest and welfare and shall have the sole discretion to grant or deny the application based on the information presented. (d) A decision by the board of commissioners shall be made within 30 days from the date of the board of commissioners meeting, and notice of that decision shall be mailed to the applicant within ten days thereafter. In the event the application is denied, the written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reason for the denial and shall notify the applicant of his right to appeal; the appeal shall be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Sec. 4-61. - Issuance of license. Upon approval by the board of commissioners of the application for a license, the county clerk shall issue a license in the following name, as appropriate according to the approved application: (1) When the applicant is applying for himself and a corporation or club, the license shall be issued in the name of the approved applicant and the corporation or club. (2) If the applicant is a partnership, the license shall be issued in the name of one or more partners in the partnership. (3) If the applicant is an individual, the license shall be issued in the name of the individual. Sec. 4-62. - Display of license; separate license required for each licensed premises. Each licensee of the county shall display the license issued hereunder prominently at all times at the premises for which the license is issued. A separate license must be issued for each licensed premises. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. Secs. 4-63—4-82. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DENIAL OF ISSUANCE OR RENEWAL, SUSPENSION, AND REVOCATION
Sec. 4-83. - Reapplication after denial. In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant may not reapply for the same type of license for at least one year from the final date of the denial. Sec. 4-84. - Grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of license. The following shall be considered just cause for denial to issue, suspension, or revocation of a license hereunder: (1) Performance of any act prohibited by this chapter or the failure to perform any act required by this chapter, as well as the violation of any law, state or federal, relating to the business of the licensee. If such act, omission, or violation is done by an agent, servant, employee, or officer of the licensee, lack of knowledge on the part of the licensee or the lack of authorization for such act, omission, or violation shall be no defense; (2) Any misstatement or concealment of fact in the application that shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury or false swearing under the law; (3) Conviction of or entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by any applicant, licensee, owner, or partner, or any officer, director, or stockholder holding the controlling interest of a licensee or applicant corporation with respect to a charge of violation of any of the federal or state laws relating to the business of the applicant or licensee, or any crime, felony, or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; (4) Occurrence on two or more occasions within any 12-month period any instance of fighting, disorderly conduct, drunkenness, breach of the peace, and other similar conduct on the licensee's premises, whether the same was committed by the licensee, employees, agents, customers, or others; (5) Any other act or omission with respect to the operation of a business licensed or proposed license hereunder that the board of commissioners finds to be contrary to the public interest or that renders the applicant, the licensee, or the business location unsuitable for the continued operation of the business. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § II; Res. of 5-3-1988, § I; Ord. of 7-28-1993) State Law reference— Discretion and due process regarding local licensure, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 4-85. - Procedure for reconsideration of refusal to grant or renew license. (a) In the event the board of commissioners should refuse to grant any license or to renew any license previously granted, the applicant shall have the right to request the board of commissioners to advise in writing the reason for refusal. (b) The applicant shall further have the right, within ten days of receipt of the written reasons for refusal, to request a hearing for reconsideration before the board of commissioners and shall be entitled to present evidence in his behalf as to why the license should be issued. Evidence shall also be admissible to show why the license should not be issued. (c) After the hearing, the board of commissioners shall make a finding as to whether the license or license renewal should be granted or denied and, if denied, shall state the reason for denial. Sec. 4-86. - Procedure for license suspension or revocation. (a) In the event that any license is temporarily suspended by any authorized officer of the county, including the sheriff, the license shall be turned over to the board of commissioners' office immediately, and the licensee shall appear before the board of commissioners at a regular meeting for consideration of continued suspension, permanent revocation, or reinstatement. (b) Prior to the suspension or revocation of any license, a hearing shall be held before the board of commissioners. The licensee shall be given ten days written notice of the hearing. The notice shall contain the date, place, and time of the hearing and the alleged reasons being considered for the suspension or revocation. The licensee shall have the right at the hearing, individually or through a representative, to examine and cross examine witnesses and to introduce oral and documentary evidence. (c) The board of commissioners shall determine whether a license shall be suspended or revoked and, if suspended, for what period of time, after consideration of the evidence in the cause and in accordance with the findings as to the severity of the offense, if any, found to have been committed. Sec. 4-87. - Rehearing. (a) Any person aggrieved by the act of the county with respect to licensure suspension or revocation shall have the right to move for a rehearing. Motion for a rehearing shall be filed within five days after the act or omission complained of, shall be in writing, and shall outline the manner in which such aggrieved party believes that the county erred. (b) If the motion relates to a matter as to which evidence has already been heard, no additional evidence or argument shall be permitted in the motion for rehearing except after a grant of permission therefor by the board of commissioners. (c) If the subject matter that forms the basis of the complaint of the aggrieved party is not the subject of a prior hearing at which the aggrieved party was permitted to be present and heard, the board of commissioners shall afford a hearing within ten days after the filing of the motion, of which reasonable notice shall be given to all parties known to the board of commissioners to be interested and at which persons interested in protesting or supporting the act or omission of the county shall be allowed to appear, be represented, introduce oral and documentary evidence, and examine and cross examine witnesses. Secs. 4-88—4-117. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYEE PERMITS
Sec. 4-118. - Employment permit required; application; fingerprints. Before any person may work on a licensed premises, he shall file a notice with the licensing officer of his intended employment and an application for a permit therefor on forms supplied by the licensing officer and shall, upon approval, receive a permit evidencing approval of such employment from the licensing officer. The prospective employee shall supply such information as the licensing officer requires, including a set of fingerprints, on regular county or federal forms. Upon approval, the employee may begin working on the licensed premises. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-119. - Permit period. Employee permits shall expire annually on November 30, and application for renewal thereof, together with fees as provided herein, is due on December 1 of each year. Sec. 4-120. - Nonrefundable investigation fee; permit fee. (a) Investigation fee. A nonrefundable investigation fee shall accompany the notice of intended employment and application for employment permit. The investigation fee shall be in the amount established from time to time by the board of commissioners as shown in the county's fee schedule. (b) Permit fee. In addition to the investigation fee, each application for original issuance and renewal of an employee permit shall be accompanied by an annual fee in the amount established by the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-121. - Qualifications. Employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall be not less than 18 years of age. Every employee must be of good moral character as defined in this chapter. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-122. - Effect of criminal convictions. Any employee who is convicted of a crime constituting a felony or a crime not a felony involving moral turpitude while employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee shall not thereafter be eligible for a permit hereunder or work on any licensed premises for a period of five years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-123. - Denial of employment permit. If the application for permit for employment is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of said denial, apply to the licensing officer for a hearing. The decision of the licensing officer after hearing may be appealed to the board of county commissioners or its designee who may issue such order as is proper in the premises. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-124. - Suspension or revocation of approval of employment. Violation of the provisions of this Code, other county ordinances, or county or state laws and regulations shall subject an employee to suspension or revocation of his employment under this article. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Sec. 4-125. - Independent contractors considered employees. For the purpose of this article, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and shall be subject to the permit requirements of this article as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or licensee of any adult entertainment establishment. (Ord. of 6-22-1993, § 1(10)) Secs. 4-126—4-148. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local excise taxes on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; excise taxes on malt beverages to be paid by wholesale dealer, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81; prohibition on requirement for markings on beverage containers regarding excise taxes, O.C.G.A. § 35-5-82; local excise taxes on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-60.
Sec. 4-149. - Tax imposed. (a) Beer in bottles, cans, and similar containers. The county does hereby levy a tax on the sale of malt beverages of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces sold by wholesalers to licensees under this chapter. (b) Tap, draft, or draught beer in kegs, barrels, or other bulk containers. There is also levied by the county an excise tax on the sale of tap, draft, or draught beer of $6.00 per each container of not more than 15 1/2 gallons and a like rate for fractional parts in the event the beer is sold in or from barrel or bulk containers. (c) Wine and distilled spirits. There is hereby levied an excise tax of $0.22 per liter on wines and distilled spirits and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (d) Table of sample calculations for standard container sizes. The following table contains sample calculations of the excise taxes imposed in this section for standard packaging sizes. The table is intended as a sample and reference only and shall in no way modify the amount of excise tax imposed in this section.
(e) Applicability. The excise taxes levied herein shall not apply within the incorporated limits of any municipality within the county if the city levies a similar excise tax. State Law reference— Local excise tax on sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; local excise tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60; local excise tax on distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80. Sec. 4-150. - Collection and payment by wholesaler; monthly reports. (a) Every wholesaler is charged with the duty of paying the excise taxes on beer and wine provided for in this article. The taxes shall be paid to the county clerk on or before the tenth day of the month, based on the units of malt beverage and wine sold during the previous month. Interest shall accrue on late payments at the rate of 12 percent per annum. (b) Every wholesaler charged with the duty of paying excises taxes as set forth in this article shall file a report with the county clerk monthly itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact qualities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, sold during the month within the county. Every wholesaler shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments and shall submit a sworn statement verifying the same with the monthly report to the county clerk. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VIII; Res. of 5-3-1988, § VII) Secs. 4-151—4-168. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - REGULATIONS
Sec. 4-169. - Location restrictions. (a) No license shall be issued for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages nor for the on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages in any location that is prohibited by state law. (b) In addition, no license shall be issued for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages nor for the sale for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages for any business that is located on a parcel of land, the property line of that is nearer than 400 feet to the property line of any school grounds or church grounds, unless a more stringent state law applies. (c) For purposes of this section, distances shall be measured by airline measurement from property line to property line, using the closest property lines of the parcels of land involved. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § III; Res. of 5-3-1988, § II) Sec. 4-170. - Alcoholic beverage sales and purchase records. Every licensee shall keep and preserve records of all alcoholic beverages purchased and sold by the licensee. The records shall be kept for a period of three years from the date of purchase and sale and should at all times be open to audit or inspection by the board of commissioners, any designated county employee, any outside agent for the county, upon approval of the outside agent by the county. State Law reference— Record of sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-6. Sec. 4-171. - Adult entertainment; obscene acts. (a) No licensee shall permit on the licensed premises: (1) Any person performing acts of, or acts that constitute or simulate: a. Sexual intercourse; b. Masturbation; c. Sodomy; d. Bestiality; e. Oral copulation; f. Flagellation; or g. Any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; (2) The touching, caressing, or fondling of the: a. Breast; b. Buttocks; c. Anus; or d. Genitals; (3) The displaying of any portion of the: a. Areola of the breast; b. Pubic hair; c. Cleft of the buttocks; d. Anus; e. Vulva; or f. Genitals; or (4) The showing, display, or exhibit of any: a. Film; b. Still picture; c. Electronic reproduction; or d. Any other visual reproduction or image of any act or conduct described in this subsection. (b) No licensee shall permit on the licensed premises any person using artificial devices or inanimate objects to depict any of the prohibited activities described above. (c) No licensee shall permit any person to remain in or about the licensed premises who exposes to public view any portion of the areola of the breast, or any portion of the pubic hair, cleft of the buttocks, anus, vulva, or genitals. (d) There shall be no nude, seminude, or erotic dancing, or the performance of obscene acts or acts, in any premises that is licensed, which simulate: (1) Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; (2) The touching, caressing, or fondling of the breast, buttock, anus, or genitals; or (3) The displaying of the pubic hair, anus, vulva, or genitals. (e) The holding, promotion, or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night, or any other sexual activity is prohibited in any licensed premises. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-40 et seq. Sec. 4-172. - Soliciting purchases prohibited. No person employed or working in any capacity at any licensed premises shall solicit or encourage patrons to purchase drinks to be consumed by or otherwise disposed of by the person so employed or working. Sec. 4-173. - Adulteration of product. No licensee shall add to the contents of a bottle or refill an empty bottle or in any other manner misrepresent the quantity, quality, or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. State Law reference— Adulteration or misbranding of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 51-1-24. Sec. 4-174. - Sanitary condition required for premises. The licensee shall keep the premises clean, and in proper sanitary condition, and in full compliance with provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption and as provided by the rules and regulations of the county board of health. Sec. 4-175. - Inspections. Any officials that may be authorized by the board of commissioners including, but not by way of limitation, the county's sheriff and deputy sheriffs, other law enforcement officers, county code enforcement officers, and the county's fire chief or his designees, shall have the authority to inspect the premises and premises licensed under this chapter during the hours when the premises is open for business. These inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other county, state, or federal officials to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of law. Sec. 4-176. - Responsibility of employer. The licensee is responsible for the conduct or actions of his employees while in his employment. It shall be the duty of the licensee hereunder to maintain a copy of this chapter at the premises and to instruct each and every employee engaged in the sale or handling of alcoholic beverages of the terms hereof. Sec. 4-177. - Sales contrary to law prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to sell alcoholic beverages upon the licensed premises, or permit alcoholic beverages to be consumed thereon, on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited by law. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VI; Res. of 5-3-1988, § V) Sec. 4-178. - Delivery of alcoholic beverages restricted. Alcoholic beverages shall be received at or delivered to the premises of the retail licensee by no other means than by a conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale dealer with a permit from the county to make deliveries in the county. Transportation of malt beverages by any other means shall be grounds for revocation of a wholesale permit. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VI; Res. of 5-3-1988, § V) Sec. 4-179. - Advertising restricted. No retail or wholesale dealer licensed by the county shall advertise the sale of alcoholic beverages through the utilization of exterior signs of any type or through the use of promotional products or displays which can be seen from the exterior of the business establishment, except as may otherwise be permitted by state law. Such signs or markings as are customarily put upon containers, cases, or cartons containing said beverages by the distributors thereof shall not be considered as advertising under the terms and provisions of this section. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § VI; Res. of 5-3-1988, § V) Sec. 4-180. - Hours and days of sale; election day and Sunday sales. (a) The hours of operation of retail licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be all hours and days during which the sale of alcoholic beverages is permitted pursuant to state law. The hours of operation of a wholesale licensee for the distribution of malt beverages within the county shall be between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., except on Sunday. (b) There shall be no alcoholic beverages sold or distributed within the county on Sundays, or any other days prohibited by state law. (c) It shall be lawful to sell wine and malt beverages in the unincorporated areas of the county during the polling hours of any election; provided, however, that no alcoholic beverages may be sold within 250 feet of a polling place during such a time as the polls are opened. (Res. of 4-25-1985, § IX; Res. of 5-3-1988, § VIII; Ord. of 10-10-1988, § I) State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; sales on election days, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. Sec. 4-181. - Additional regulations for premises licensed for consumption on the premises. In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall comply with the following restrictions: (1) No alcoholic beverages shall be sold from 12:00 midnight to 7:00 a.m. and no malt beverage may be consumed on the premises from 1:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. (2) The licensee may hold said license only so long as at least one meal per day shall be served to the general public from the premises at least six days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations, and periods of redecorating, and the serving of such meals shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of malt beverage and wine to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto.
