Additional lighting, including but not limited to, neon, animation and running lights is prohibited. (3) Height above grade. All signs shall be a minimum of ten feet above adjacent pavement measuring from the lower portion of the sign face. (4) Extrusions prohibited. Extrusions beyond the face of the sign, excluding aprons, are prohibited. (5) Number of signs per location. No more than two sign faces may be visible from the same direction on said highway. Double-faced, back-to-back, and V-type constructed signs shall, for the purpose of determining compliance with size and spacing limitations, be considered as one sign. Double-faced signs shall be one continuous physically connected structure constructed in a horizontal straight line with two abutting displays (faces) facing one direction of travel. Sign displays may not be placed one above the other. (6) Spacing. Sign locations shall be no more than 1,000 feet apart measuring from the closest points. All off-premises outdoor advertising signs shall be located only within a C-GB, I-1 or I-2 zone. (7) Quantity. No more than three outdoor advertising signs may be constructed and located on each quadrant of any intersection of any public road or street. These signs are restricted to an area 1,200 feet long beginning 100 feet from the intersection. (8) Park land and historic area locations prohibited. No sign shall be placed in or obstruct the view of a park land area or an area of designated historic interest. (9) On-premises signs. On-premises signs located within 100 feet of a regularly used part of the activity being advertised and located on the same property and "for sale" or "for lease" signs located on the property being advertised are not prohibited; provided, however, said sign shall not exceed 50 feet in height as measured from the level of the surface of the pavement of the nearest lane of the main traveled way. (10) Height restrictions off-premises outdoor advertising signs. The total height of the sign may not exceed 50 feet above the level of the surface of the pavement of the nearest lane of the main traveled way or 50 feet from the ground at the base of the sign to the tallest part of the structure, including the display or face and its trim, whichever is greater. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XI, § 11.5) Sec. 34-24. - Nonconforming signs. Any legally erected sign which would become nonconforming as a result of this article shall be allowed to remain until purchased by the department of transportation or the county, provided that the sign owner meets the requirements of state laws and rules and regulations governing such signs. Any existing nonconforming outdoor advertising sign located on a county roadway or state route may be rebuilt in the event the same is destroyed by a natural disaster unless otherwise prohibited by law. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XI, § 11.6) Sec. 34-25. - Regulations for specific types of signs. (a) Signs of work under construction . One nonilluminated sign not exceeding 40 square feet in area displaying the name of the building, the contractors, the architects, the engineers, the owners, the financial, selling and development agencies is permitted upon the premises of any work under the construction, alteration, or removal. Such sign shall be removed from the site within 30 days after the completion of the project. (b) Temporary subdivision signs . Temporary signs, not exceeding 40 square feet in area announcing a land subdivision development developer, builder, or agent may be erected and maintained, provided: (1) The size of any such sign is not in excess of six square feet, and not in excess of four feet in length; and (2) Not more than one such sign is erected on each 500 feet of right-of-way frontage. (c) Roof signs . Not more than one roof sign structure may be erected on the roof of any one building. No roof sign structure shall extend more than 25 feet above the elevation of the roof. (d) Wall signs . Signs on the walls of a building (including signs attached flat against the wall, painted wall signs, are permitted on the premises of the land subdivision. Such signs shall be spaced not less than 300 feet apart. They shall be removed when 75 percent of the lots are conveyed. (e) Private directional signs . Signs indicating the location and direction of premises available for or in process of development, but not erected upon such premises, and having inscribed thereon the name of the owner, and projecting signs) shall meet the following requirements. (1) Total area—Front of building. The total area of signs on the exterior front surface of a building shall not exceed 25 percent of the front surface of the building. (2) Same—Side or rear of building. The total area of signs on a side or rear surface of building shall not exceed 50 percent of the exterior side or rear surface of the building, respectively. (f) Projecting signs. Wall signs attached flat against a wall may extend not more than 24 inches from the wall. Signs attached at an angle to a wall may extend outward from the wall of a building not more than five feet. (g) Illuminated signs . Illuminated devices shall be so placed on so shielded that light from the sign itself will be directly cast into any residential district, sleeping rooms in any district or the eyes of an automobile or vehicular driver. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § III(1)—(7)) Sec. 34-26. - Permitted on-premises signs. On-premises signs located within 100 feet of a regularly used part of the activity being advertised and located on the same property and for sale or for lease signs located on the property being advertised would not be prohibited. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § III(9)) Secs. 34-27—34-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INTERSTATE 20 SIGN REGULATIONS
Sec. 34-56. - Applicability; compliance required. This article shall apply to outdoor advertising signs abutting or visible from the Interstate 20 right-of-way in the county. No sign shall be erected or maintained unless it is in compliance with the regulations of this article. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § I(1), (2)) Sec. 34-57. - Nonconforming signs. Any legally erected sign that would become nonconforming as a result of this article would be allowed to remain until purchased by the department of transportation or the county, provided that the sign owner is in compliance with state laws and rules and regulations governing such signs. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § III(10)) Sec. 34-58. - Sign construction; state law; obsolete signs. (a) Signs must be constructed of durable materials, maintained in good condition, and not permitted to become dilapidated. (b) All signs located on sites abutting or visible from the Interstate 20 right-of-way shall conform to O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq., and shall meet all federal and state requirements necessary to obtain a permit under said law, rules, and regulations. In instances where the sign controls of this article are more stringent, these regulations shall apply. (c) Any signs that advertise an activity, business, product or service that has ceased operation or production shall be removed within six months of the discontinuance of said activity, business, product or service. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § I(3)—(5)) Sec. 34-59. - Sign specifications. Outdoor advertising signs shall meet the following requirements: (1) Uniform size . The outside measurements of all such signs shall be 12 feet in height and 50 feet in length, with or without trim. (2) Illumination . All illuminated signs shall use base mounted fluorescent or mercury vapor lights and shall be activated by photo-electric cells. Additional lighting including but not limited to neon, animation and running lights is prohibited. (3) Height above interstate grade . All signs shall be a minimum of ten feet above adjacent interstate pavement measuring from the lower portion of the sign face. Signs shall not exceed 30 feet in height. Two signs in the same location (back-to-back) or "V" formation shall be the same height above the interstate's surface. (4) Extrusions prohibited . Extrusions beyond the face of the sign, excluding aprons, are prohibited. (5) Number of signs per location . Only one sign shall be allowed to face the same direction per location. This allows back-to-back or "V" formation signs but prohibits two signs (side-by-side) facing the same direction. (6) Spacing . Sign locations shall be no less than 500 feet apart measuring from the two closest points. (7) Setback requirement. Sign structures shall be no less than ten feet from any property or right-of-way line. (8) Signs in interchange quadrants. Three outdoor advertising signs per quadrant of an interchange adjacent to the interstate highway shall be allowed. These signs must be within 600 feet of an ongoing commercial or industrial activity as specified in state law and are restricted to an area 1,200 feet long beginning 500 feet from the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp. (9) Obstruction of marsh and historical locations prohibited . No sign shall be placed in or obstruct the view of a marshland or an area of designated historic interest. (10) Advertisement limitations . Outdoor advertising shall be limited to the following: a. Travel service facilities, including lodgings, gas, food and camping; b. Areas of scenic beauty; c. Public attractions including historic, natural scientific or recreational amenities; and d. Any combination of the facilities listed in this subsection. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § III(8)) Sec. 34-60. - Prohibited signs. (a) Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles; nor shall any signs use the words, slogans, dimensional shape and size, or colors of the governmental traffic signs. (b) No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. (c) Signs painted or attached to natural features such as trees or rocks, telephone poles, utility poles, or fence posts are prohibited. (d) Fluttering ribbons and banners are prohibited. (e) Signs within 300 feet of any officially designated historical site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument are prohibited. (Ord. of 6-4-1985, § II)

div.head: Chapter 36 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Solid waste management generally, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; hazardous waste management generally, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-60 et seq.; tire disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.1; yard trimmings and disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2; authorization for local government units to enforce collection of taxes, fees, or assessments for solid waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.3; authority of local governments to adopt and enforce local regulations for the handling and disposal of solid waste, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building rubbish means waste material resulting from construction, remodeling, repairs, and demolition operations on houses, commercial buildings and other structures, including driveways and walks, and it comprises waste and rejected matter such as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, wallpaper, sheetrock, and lathes, lumber, shingles, tile, concrete, and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing. Dumpster means a receptacle provided by the county for the disposal of household garbage. Dumpster site means any location provided to the public by the county for the purpose of disposing or dumping household garbage. Garbage means house and kitchen offal and all refuse matter composed of animal or vegetable substances. Household garbage or household waste means solid waste generated and disposed of in the normal course of residential living; animal or vegetable matter used for or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, and cooking of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables; paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, cans, bottles, glass, crockery, discarded clothing, and similar combustible and noncombustible waste not subject to rapid decomposition; and ashes, dirt, paper, and other accumulations of similar nature and small in size that would commonly be found in all households, excluding bushes, trees, limbs, large boxes, planks, boards, old furniture, scrap metal, and any and all other items that are too large to fit in a dumpster. Yard rubbish means tree branches, stumps, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings, bushes, weeds, leaves, and general yard and garden waste materials and includes stone and dirt rakings and any waste materials resulting from landscaping. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § II) Sec. 36-2. - Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-13 in combination with any or all of the following additional penalties: (1) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the day of execution of sentence. (2) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public beach, public park, private right-of-way or, with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. (3) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be ordered to pay restitution in an amount determined by the court to reimburse the county for any damages incurred as a result of the person's violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § V) Sec. 36-3. - State law adopted. The county adopts and incorporates by reference in this chapter the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § III) Secs. 36-4—36-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Sec. 36-25. - Container requirements. The owner, agent, and occupant of any premises, improved or unimproved, in the unincorporated area of the county wherein garbage shall be created shall provide a suitable container for the storage and disposition of the garbage. The container shall be fly-proof and rodent-proof. (Min. of 10-2-1973) Sec. 36-26. - Accumulation prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, and/or occupant of any such premises to have, maintain or keep garbage on any premises except at such sites as may be approved by the department of natural resources, environmental protection unit, for the disposition of solid waste, except in containers of the type required by this article. The owner, agent, and/or occupant shall also keep clean, free from rubbish and similar loose materials, all premises, whether improved or unimproved, as well as all open lots and areas. (Min. of 10-2-1973) Sec. 36-27. - Dumping prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, and/or occupant, or other person to dispose of, or dump, or leave waste upon property of others and upon the roadways kept and maintained by the county, except in areas specifically designated by the county, for the disposal and disposition of solid waste, said areas being marked on a map in the office of the board of county commissioners, and said areas being provided with a dumpster in which all of said waste shall be deposited. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to dump any tree limb, tire, refrigerator, air conditioner, stove, motor vehicle, motor vehicle body part, washer, dryer, household garbage, any item which is constructed, in whole or in part, of wood, metal, cement, rubber, and/or glass in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, or on any public lands except in dumpsters or areas designated by lawful authority. (Min. of 10-2-1973) Sec. 36-28. - Burning prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, and/or occupant of any such premises to burn, or cause to be burned, any garbage, domestic waste, or other debris required by the terms and provisions of this article to be kept and maintained in garbage containers and other solid waste materials not specifically exempted by the terms and provisions of this article and/or items for which a permit for burning may be obtained from the county. (Min. of 10-2-1973) Sec. 36-29. - Hazardous waste prohibited. No hazardous waste facility shall be located, permitted, operated, or established in the county. (Ord. of 9-4-1980) Sec. 36-30. - Garbage collection times restricted. No garbage, refuse, or recyclable collector shall perform collection in residential areas before 6:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m. Secs. 36-31—36-48. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DUMPSTER REGULATIONS
Sec. 36-49. - Household garbage only permitted. (a) All dumpsters provided at dumpster sites by the county shall be designated as being suitable for household garbage only. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump any refuse or other material into the container other than household garbage. (b) It shall be unlawful to deposit nonhousehold garbage items in or around any dumpster site. This prohibition shall specifically apply to, but not be limited to, old furniture, construction materials, dead animals, scrap metal, yard rubbish, building rubbish, furniture, appliances, motor vehicle parts, motor vehicle tires, lawn mowers, dangerous materials or substances such as poisons, acids, caustics, and explosives and any other nonhousehold waste. All such articles or items shall be deposited at the county sanitary landfill. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § IV(a), (e); Ord. of 5-3-1994, § 3; Ord. of 3-6-1998) Sec. 36-50. - Burning, littering, vandalism, and scavenging prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to the contents of, indiscriminately scatter or disperse the contents of, or otherwise vandalize any containers provided by the county for the dumping of household garbage. It shall be unlawful to scavenge through the contents of dumpsters at any dumpster site. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § IV(b), (c); Ord. of 3-6-1998) Sec. 36-51. - Deposit of garbage outside container prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful to deposit any household garbage on the ground at a dumpster site unless all dumpsters at said site are filled to capacity. (Ord. of 7-1-1986, § IV(d); Ord. of 3-6-1998) Sec. 36-52. - Waste originating outside county. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or to cause to be placed any household waste originating from any household or other source outside of the county in or around any dumpster located within the boundaries of the county. (Ord. of 5-3-1994, § 2)

div.head: Chapter 38 - STREETS, ROADS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Highways, bridges and ferries generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-1 et seq.; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; Mass Gathering Act, O.C.G.A. § 31-27-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ROAD MAINTENANCE (RESERVED)
Secs. 38-19—38-41. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STREET AND ROAD NUMBERING
Sec. 38-42. - Applicability. All parcels of subdivided land in the county shall have a street or road number assigned. The county zoning and permit officer or his designee shall be responsible for assigning these numbers in a logical, unbiased manner such that emergency response personnel and general delivery vehicles shall be assisted in the efficient discharge of their duties. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-1) Sec. 38-43. - Display of numbers required. (a) Every house, mobile home, individual apartment, business, or other building having a street or road number assigned to it under the system of numbering in the unincorporated limits of the county shall display such street or road number in a readily visible manner and in compliance with the requirements of this section. (b) Mobile home parks, manufactured home parks, and apartment complexes shall also be required to have each individual pad, lot number or apartment building numbered in a multi-building development displayed in a readily visible manner from the main street or road or thoroughfare through the mobile home park, manufactured home park, or apartment complex and in compliance with the requirements of this article. Each lot, pad, or apartment building number shall be in sequence unless directional signs are provided for numbers not in sequence. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-2) Sec. 38-44. - Required for issuance of certificate of occupancy. Prior to issuing a certificate for occupancy for any new residence in the unincorporated limits of the county, the county permit and zoning office shall verify the presence of mandatory minimum standard street or road numbering in accordance with this article. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-2.1) Sec. 38-45. - Sign placement regulations. (a) Assigned street or road numbers shall be permanently affixed to the house, mobile home, manufactured home, apartment, business, or other building itself, provided that the structure is not more than 50 feet from the curbside, pavement edge or edge of the travel way of the street or road in front of the structure and the number is readily visible from the street or road by persons traveling along the street or road in each direction. (b) The street or road number must be located under a night (porch, garage) light where such a light exists in such manner that the number is visible at night when the light is lighted. (c) For structures located not more than 50 feet from the curbside, pavement edge, or edges of the travel way of the street or road in front of the structure, the street or road numbers shall also be placed on both sides of an individual's mailbox such that when the "arm" or "flag" is in the up or down position, the number is not hidden or blocked. (d) If the structure is more than 50 feet from the curbside, pavement edge, or edge of the travel way of the street or road in front of the structure, the street or road number, the number may, in addition or in lieu of placement on the structure's mailbox, be placed on signs located on the premises in front of the structure; provided, however, that: (1) The signs must be of a durable type and must be located not more than 50 feet from the curbline, pavement edge or edge of the travel way of the street or road in front of the property. (2) The number on such signs shall be readily visible from the street or road by a person traveling along the street or road in each direction. (3) The signs must not exceed two square feet in size. (4) The signs may be illuminated in a manner that does not disturb residents of adjacent properties. (5) The signs must not be placed in the county or state right-of-way nor block line of sight from any egress or entry point and the county street or road corner line of sight. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-3) Sec. 38-46. - Minimum size and type of numbers. (a) Street or road numbers affixed to buildings shall be a minimum of four inches in height and the number may be of highly reflective material if the numbers are lighted by a night light affixed to the building. If no night (porch, garage) light is affixed to the building, then the numbers must be displayed with a background of highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware or building supply store). (b) Numbers affixed to mailboxes in the manner specified in this article shall be a minimum of three inches in height and must be displayed on highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware or building supply store). Numbers displayed in the front yard on a sign must be four inches in height and may be either contrasting color with the background or with a highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware or building supply store). All such numbers not designed with a reflective background shall be of a color contrasting to the background so as to be clearly visible. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-4) Sec. 38-47. - Maintenance requirements. Street or road numbers on buildings and signs, and the signs to which they are affixed, shall be maintained at all times in good condition. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-4) Sec. 38-48. - Duty of owner; violations. The obligation of complying with the provisions of this article shall be upon the owner of the property. If the provisions of this article are violated, notice shall be given to the owner of the property, or his agent, specifying the manner in which this article is being violated, and giving the owner 30 days to bring the property into compliance. Each day a violation of this article continues after the expiration date of the 30-day period shall constitute a separate offense each of which shall be punishable as provided in section 1-13. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-5) Sec. 38-49. - Responsibility of enforcement. The responsibility for making the inspections provided for in this article and for the enforcement of the provisions hereof shall rest upon the board of county commissioners or its designated representative, who is hereby authorized and empowered to make cases and issue written warnings. Any such warnings issued shall be forwarded to the county marshal. Upon expiration of any such warnings, all law enforcement agencies providing services to the unincorporated limits of the county are authorized to issue summonses for violations. (Res. of 3-5-2002, § 5-7) Secs. 38-50—38-71. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - TIMBER HARVESTING[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. of Feb. 6, 2018, §§ 1, 2, repealed former Art. IV, §§ 38-72—38-75, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of July 7, 1992, §§ 1—3.
Sec. 38-72. - Purpose and intent. This article is intended to require notice of timber harvesting operations within the unincorporated areas of Haralson County pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24, and, in accordance with Title 32 of the Official Code of Georgia, provide regulations further governing use of public roads by persons engaged in said timber harvesting operations in order to assure the public safety and to protect the county roadways and environments. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-73. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Chairman means the Chairman of the Board of Commissioners of Haralson County, or his or her designee. Notice means the notice required to be given to the public works department by the timber harvester as provided herein. Person means any natural person, firm, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other legal entity of whatever form. Public works department means the Haralson County Public Works Department. Public works director means the Director of the Haralson County Public Works Department. Surety bond means a valid surety bond, executed by a surety corporation authorized to transact business in the State of Georgia, protecting the county against any damage cause by such person or firm in an amount specified by the governing authority of Haralson County not exceeding $5,000.00 or, at the option of the Timber Harvester, a valid irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 7-1-4, in the amount of $5,000.00 in lieu of such bond. Any such surety bond or letter of credit shall be in form prescribed by or acceptable to the chairman and shall be for the calendar year in which delivered. Timber means softwood or hardwood trees harvested for commercial purposes. Timber harvester means any person harvesting standing timber in any unincorporated area of Haralson County, Georgia for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts, or wood chips to any wood-yard or processing plant located inside or outside the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-74. - Notice required. Written notice shall be required of any timber harvester harvesting timber in the unincorporated areas of the county for each separate tract to be harvested. Said written notice shall be: (a) Delivered to the public works department prior to entering onto the subject tract, if possible, but in no event later than 24 hours after entering onto said tract; and (b) In such form and containing such information as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24(b)(1). Notice shall be effective only as to the tract described therein upon receipt by the public works department (as confirmed by written acknowledgment from said public works department to the timber harvester) and compliance with all other applicable requirements of this article. Such notice may be given in person, by transmission of an electronic record via tele facsimile, e-mail, or such other means as approved by the governing authority of the county, or by mail. Prior to and at all times during any timber harvesting operations subject to this article, the timber harvester shall additionally ensure that the requisite notice is continuously posted and displayed in good condition and in a conspicuous location on each tract of land identified in said notice. For purposes of this section, the notice shall be deemed posted in a "conspicuous location" if clearly visible and located in the immediate vicinity where the entrance road or trail providing vehicular access to the subject tract meets the nearest public right-of-way. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-75. - Surety bond. (a) A surety bond shall not be required prior to notice becoming effective. However, following the giving of any notice, in the event that the public works director determines that any activities relating to the timber harvesting are being conducted that pose likelihood of damage to any public rights-of-way or danger to the public safety, the public works department shall be authorized to demand a surety bond from the timber harvester. The surety bond shall be delivered to the public works department within three business days following receipt of written demand for the same, unless within said time a written notice of appeal is received by the public works department contesting the requirement of the surety bond. In the event of such contest, the public works department shall, no later than five business days, schedule an administrative hearing in such matter before the chairman, who shall deliver a decision within three business days of said hearing. The decision of the chairman shall be conclusive and binding for all purposes. Following any contest as provided above, all timber harvesting authorized pursuant to the applicable notice shall be suspended until the surety bond, if any, is delivered to the public works department as required by the chairman. (b) The amount of the bond shall not exceed $5,000.00. The bond shall indemnify the county against any and all damage caused, as a result of the timber harvesting and related activities, to any county roads, rights-of-way, points of egress or other public property. The surety bond shall also indemnify the county for any costs incurred in the cleanup of waste or debris left on public property as a result of the timber harvesting. (c) Upon completion of any necessary repairs to public property and removal of all waste and debris, the county will release the timber harvester from the surety bond. (d) In no event shall the delivery of a surety bond limit the liability of any person engaged in timber harvesting and related activities for damages to public property or rights-of-way or for other personal injury or property damage. (e) No more than one surety bond shall be required at any one time from a timber harvester hereunder regardless of the number of tracts harvested in the unincorporated areas of the county so long as said surety bond remains in effect; provided that a valid replacement surety bond must be obtained and delivered to the public works department no later than the close of business on the fifth day following the day that the county files a claim to recover damages against the then-existing surety bond. Upon filing such claim, the public works department or other designee of the county shall immediately provide notice thereof, including the date such claim was filed, to the person causing the damage. Such notice may be given by person, by transmission of an electronic record via tele facsimile, or by e-mail. For purposes of the section, any such surety bond shall be valid only for the calendar year in which delivered. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-76. - Culverts. Prior to commencing any timber harvesting operations, the public works director shall inspect the point of access to the public road from the tract described in the notice in order to determine its suitability. If a culvert is required at the point of access, it shall be promptly installed by the timber harvester as directed by the public works director. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-77. - Signs. Prior to commencing any timber harvesting operations, the timber harvester shall post two signs in each direction from the point of access onto the involved public road. One sign at a distance of 1,000 feet from the point of access stating "Warning: Logging Operations Ahead," and one sign at a distance of 500 feet stating "Slow Truck Entering Highway." All signs shall be 36 inches × 36 inches, erected in a diamond shape, painted orange with black legend and posted at least three feet from the travel surface of the roadway. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-78. - Roadway safety. During the period of operations, the timber harvester shall comply with the following: (1) All harvesting operations shall be conducted on the tract identified in the notice and off public roads and rights-of-way. Logging and skidding of logs on public roads and rights-of-way are strictly prohibited. (2) Ditches constituting a part of the public drainage system or otherwise benefitting a public right-of-way shall be kept clear of all debris and residue at all times to permit proper drainage. (3) There shall be no blockage of public roads or rights-of-way at the access site, and all public roads and rights-of-way must remain open and kept free of debris and residue at all times. (4) No equipment, trucks, trailers, or other personal property shall be parked or located on any public road or right-of-way. Mud shall not be carried onto paved public roads by logging vehicles. Where necessary, a temporary construction exit of gravel shall be maintained by the timber harvester to eliminate any hazard to traffic or unsightly conditions on the public right-of-way. (5) During periods of rain or inclement weather, logging vehicles shall not be operated over the unimproved public roads when such travel causes sufficient damage to the road system that the passage of smaller and lighter vehicles is hampered. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-79. - Enforcement. (a) Upon notice from the issuing authority, work on any project that is being done contrary to the provisions of this article shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the timber harvester and the owner of the subject property, and shall state the conditions under which work may resume. When an emergency exists, written notice shall not be required. (b) If the conditions are not brought into compliance within five business days of the notice, the public works department shall be authorized to accomplish the work (with costs thereof to be reimbursed by the timber harvester), and any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-80. - Concluding operations. (a) The timber harvester shall give written notification to the public works director within 24 hours following completion of the timber harvesting operations. The public works director shall inspect all affected public property and public rights-of-way to assure that the same has not been damaged or has been restored to its original condition, including any shaping of ditches, grading or seeding as required. The timber harvester shall be notified in writing of any deficiencies and given 15 business days to correct said deficiencies. If not accomplished during that period, the public works department (or its designee) shall be authorized to complete the work at the cost of the timber harvester. (b) When the public works director determines that the road and access site are in a proper state of repair, the director shall provide a written release of liability to the timber harvester. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Sec. 38-81. - Prosecution of violations. (a) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor prosecutable in the Magistrate Court of Haralson County and punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and imprisonment in the county jail for a period of no longer than 12 months. (b) The county code enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue citations in order to initiate such prosecution. (c) The imposition of any fine or other sentence pursuant to this section shall in no way limit the liability of any person for damage done to public property or public rights-of-way, and all means permitted by law or in equity, to include, without limitation the filing of a suit for damages, or the seeking of injunctive relief to stop any such damage. (Ord. of 2-6-2018, § 2) Secs. 38-82—38-93. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND ASSEMBLIES
Sec. 38-94. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in, conduct or accompany any organized parade or procession (other than a funeral procession) or assembly on the public streets, sidewalks or other public property in the county unless an application has been previously filed and a permit granted to conduct such parade, procession, or assembly within the unincorporated areas of the county. (Ord. of 1-4-1994(1), § 2) Sec. 38-95. - Application for permit. An application for permit to conduct or sponsor a parade, procession or assembly shall be filed with the county clerk in writing, and shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount established by the board of commissioners. The application shall contain the following information furnished by the person in official charge of the proposed parade, procession or assembly: (1) The name of all organizations or persons organizing or sponsoring the parade, procession or assembly; (2) The purpose of the parade, procession, or assembly; (3) The date and hours of the parade, procession, or assembly; (4) The proposed route of the parade or procession or location of assembly and its beginning and termination points; (5) The number and types of vehicles, marching units, and floats to be used in the parade or procession; (6) The number of persons participating in the parade, procession, or assembly; (7) The name of the person to be responsible for cleanup of the parade, procession, or assembly. (Ord. of 1-4-1994(1), § 3) Sec. 38-96. - Issuance of permit; time and route limitations. Upon proper application to the county clerk, and provided the parade or procession is otherwise lawful and complies with the standards of this article, the written permit shall issue to be valid for a certain date, to be named by the county clerk, within 30 days from the date of issuance. In addition, the permit shall designate a particular route to be followed by the paraders and marchers and no other route shall be permitted. (Ord. of 1-4-1994(1), § 4) Sec. 38-97. - Factors to be considered regarding issuance of permit. In deciding whether to issue a permit under the provisions of this section, the county clerk shall consider, in addition to all other considerations, the following: (1) The number of persons to participate; (2) The anticipated traffic conditions at the time and date proposed for the activity; (3) The schedule of other similar activities for which permits may have been issued; (4) The adequacy of adult supervision for any minor scheduled to participate; (5) The availability of county personnel whose presence on duty may be required by the activity and the necessity to protect the general public; (6) The adequacy of public facilities in the location proposed for the activity to accommodate the proposed activity and the normal public use of public facilities in the proposed location. (Ord. of 1-4-1994(1), § 4) Sec. 38-98. - Permit holder responsible for cleanup. (a) The permit holder shall be responsible for the cleanup of any litter or debris on public property caused by the parade, procession, or assembly, including, but not limited to, any paper or other waste or debris left on the streets or roads by floats or units of parade and any paper, wrappings, flowers or other items given by parade participants to members of the public and discarded by members of the public. (b) Failure to clean up litter or debris following a parade or assembly shall constitute a violation of this article and shall upon conviction be punishable as provided in section 1-13. (c) In lieu of the cleanup required in this section, the permit holders may, at the time of obtaining a permit, pay an additional cleanup fee in the amount fixed from time to time by the board of county commissioners. Payment of the cleanup fee shall relieve the permit holder of responsibility for cleaning up of public property as required in this section. (Ord. of 1-4-1994(1), § 5)

div.head: Chapter 42 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; county tax officials and administration, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-100 et seq.; county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220 et seq.; miscellaneous local administration provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380; county sales and use taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq.; taxes on tobacco products, O.C.G.A. § 48-11-1 et seq.; levy of occupation taxes by counties and municipalities on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.; imposition of regulatory fees by local governments on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 42-1—42-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SALES AND USE TAXES
Sec. 42-19. - Imposed. A sales and use tax at the rate of one percent is hereby imposed on all sales and uses in the county. Otherwise, the tax imposed shall correspond, so far as practicable, except as to rate, with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq. (Res. of 7-5-1977) Secs. 42-20—42-41. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - AD VALOREM TAXES
Sec. 42-42. - Due date. From and after December 1, 2008, the due date of ad valorem taxes in the county shall be December 1 of each year. (Res. of 9-12-2007(1)) Sec. 42-43. - Exemption. The Freeport exemption provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.2, as approved by the voters of the county at a 20 percent tax reduction rate, shall be applicable in the county. (Res. of 8-4-1992) Secs. 42-44—42-74. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - GROSS PREMIUMS TAX
Sec. 42-75. - Imposed. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, there is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer doing insurance business within the unincorporated area of the county in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year on all insurance, other than life insurance, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 33-33-5(2), (3), (4) and (5). The term "gross direct premiums" shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). Secs. 42-76—42-93. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TAX FORECLOSURES
Sec. 42-94. - Authority of tax commissioner. The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1 et seq. shall apply in the county. The county tax commissioner shall have the authority to commence tax foreclosures and to file petitions for judicial in rem tax foreclosures for delinquent taxes with the county superior court. (Res. of 7-16-2007)

div.head: Chapter 44 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS
div.p: Sec. 44-1. - Purposes. It is the intent of the board of commissioners that the provisions of this chapter be construed so as to balance the following interests: (1) Ensuring the compatibility of proposed facilities with surrounding areas by establishing standards for location, structural design, height, structural integrity, design review, landscaping, and visual screening; (2) Sustaining the peaceful character of the county by establishing standards to reduce the potential of telecommunications facilities to produce disruptive noise, vibration, or illumination; (3) Assisting in the identification of potential sources of interference with existing telephone, radio, television, or electronic computing system currently in use in the area; (4) Allowing telecommunication facilities that are sufficient to allow adequate service to citizens, the traveling public, and others within the county and to accommodate the need for connection of such services to telecommunication facilities in adjacent and surrounding communities while at the same time considering the adverse visual impacts of these facilities on developed residential areas, agricultural areas, and natural surroundings; (5) Facilitating the use of public property for such facilities; and (6) Enhancing the ability of providers of telecommunication services to provide such service to the community quickly, effectively, and efficiently. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.1; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.1) Sec. 44-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alternative antenna support structure means manmade trees, clock towers, bell steeples, flag or light poles, and similar alternative-design mounting structures that camouflage or conceal the presence of antennas or antenna support structures. An alternative antenna support structure may have an antenna and be affixed to an existing building, overhead facilities, or the like. Antenna means mounted exterior apparatus designed for the transmission and/or reception of telephonic, radio, television, or other wireless communications and/or data. Antenna support structure means any structure designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including, but not limited to, self-supporting lattice towers, guy towers, monopole towers, and alternative antenna support structures. The term is synonymous with the terms "structure" and "tower," and includes, but is not limited to, radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, and common-carrier telephone towers. (1) Lattice tower. A telecommunications antenna support structure which consists of vertical and horizontal supports and metal crossed strips or bars to support an antenna and connecting appurtenances. The term "lattice tower" includes such towers that meet the aforementioned definition and which may or may not be supported by guy wires. (2) Monopole tower. A telecommunications antenna support structure consisting of a single pole to support an antenna and connecting appurtenances, and which is constructed with or without guy wires or ground anchors. (3) Guyed tower. Any variety of telecommunications antenna support structure that use wire guys connecting above grade portions of the structure diagonally with the ground to provide support for the structure, antennas, and/or connecting appurtenances. Applicant means any provider or any person, partnership, or company who files an application for any permit necessary to install, maintain, or remove a telecommunications service facility within the county. Board of commissioners means the board of commissioners of the county. Building permits department means the county building permits department. Collocation means the use of a common antenna support structure or common site by two or more telecommunications providers, or by one telecommunications provider for more than one antenna or for more than one type of an antenna or technology. Comprehensive plan means a plan, as amended from time to time, devised to provide the county with a guide for future growth and development in accordance with the Georgia Planning Act. Conditional zoning use or conditional use means a special use, normally prohibited by the county zoning ordinance, that must be: (1) Approved pursuant to articles XV and XVII of the county zoning ordinance; (2) Recommended by the planning commission; and (3) Approved by the commissioner. County means Haralson County. Equipment enclosure means a building or other structure, including, but not limited to, shelters, cabinets, or vaults used to house and/or store equipment used in the operation or maintenance of a telecommunications facility. FAA means the Federal Aviation Administration. FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. Height means the distance measured vertically from the highest point when positioned for operation to the lowest point which is defined as the bottom of the base of the structure being measured at either roof or ground level, whichever is applicable. The height of a tower shall include the height of any antenna positioned for operation attached or which may be attached to the highest point on the tower. Modification means the physical changing of any portion of a telecommunications facility from its description in a previously approved permit, including, but not limited to, structural design and physical appearance changes, but not necessarily technology upgrades. Planning commission means the county planning commission. Public property means any and all property owned or otherwise controlled by the county. Telecommunications Act means the Telecommunications Act of 1996, 47 USC 151 et seq., as now and hereafter amended. Telecommunications facility means that which is built, constructed, installed, or erected by or on behalf of a telecommunications provider for purposes providing or offering telecommunication services and which include as a part thereof a building, equipment enclosure, and/or antenna support structure. Telecommunications service means the providing or offering for rent, sale, lease, or in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal of voice, data, image, graphic, video programming information, and wireless communications between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite, or similar media with or without the benefit of any closed transmission medium. Zoning appeals board means the county zoning appeals board. Zoning ordinance means the county zoning ordinance adopted December 12, 2004, as amended, and which is set forth in chapter 50 of this Code. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.2; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.2) Sec. 44-3. - Exemptions. The following are exempt from the provisions of this chapter and, if otherwise meeting the requirements of the county zoning ordinance, shall be permitted in all zoning districts: (1) Industrial processing equipment and scientific or medical equipment using frequencies regulated by the FCC and that are not more than 35 feet in height as measured from the ground. (2) Antennas and related equipment not more than three feet in height that are being stored, shipped, or displayed for sale. (3) Radar systems for military and civilian communication and navigation. (4) Wireless radio utilized for temporary emergency communications in the event of a disaster. (5) Licensed amateur (ham) radio stations and citizen band stations so long as such antenna and/or antenna support structure are not more than 35 feet in height as measured from the ground. (6) Home satellite dish mesh antennas 3.5 meters or less in diameter and home satellite dish solid antennas one meter or less in diameter and microwave dishes which do not attach to cable, facilities, or structure using or crossing any public right-of-way, when used as an accessory use of the property. (7) Conventional home TV antennas not more than 35 feet in height as measured from the ground. (8) Routine maintenance or emergency repair of existing telecommunications facilities and related equipment (excluding structural work or changes in height or dimensions), provided that full compliance with this chapter is maintained. (9) A temporary telecommunications facility may be permitted for a maximum of 90 days or during an emergency declared by the board of commissioners. (10) On a case-by-case basis, the planning commission may recommend relaxing any of the provisions of this chapter, and the board of commissioners may then exempt certain telecommunications facilities from those recommended provisions only in those cases that such facilities are demonstrated to be crucial to the safety and/or welfare of the citizens of the county, and that the failure to relax such provisions would create an undue hardship of the applicant. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.3; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.3) Sec. 44-4. - Locations and antenna support structure types. (a) Preferred/disfavored/prohibited facility location sites. (1) Preferred location sites. The following list of sites shall, in the following order of preference, be preferred sites for the location of telecommunications facilities: a. Public property sites or structures; b. Collocation sites; c. Industrial or mining sites and/or structures (I-1, I-2, and M-1); d. Commercial sites and/or structures (C-OI, C-GB, and C-NB except as provided in subsections (a)(2) and (a)(3) of this section). (2) Disfavored location sites. Any property zoned for agricultural (A-1), forestry (F-1) purposes, and neighborhood business commercial (C-NB if in an area surrounded predominately by agricultural, forestry, or park/recreation/conservation land use). (3) Prohibited location sites. Any site zoned residential (R-1, R-2, R-3, R-LM, R-HM, R-MHP), neighborhood business commercial (C-NB if in an area surrounded predominately by residential land use) or planned unit development (PUD) shall be a prohibited site for the location of telecommunications facilities. (b) Antenna support structures types. (1) Favored antenna support structures. The following, in order of preference, shall be favored antenna support structures: a. Public property (capable of supporting a telecommunications antenna); b. Collocation onto existing antenna support structures; c. Alternative antenna support structures; d. Monopole towers. (2) Disfavored antenna support structures. The following shall be disfavored antenna support structures: a. Guyed towers; b. Lattice towers. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.4; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.4) Sec. 44-5. - Application procedure and requirements; permits required for the construction and/or modification of telecommunications facilities; exceptions; criteria for review. (a) Application procedure and requirements. Application for all construction and/or modification of a telecommunications facility shall be made to the building permits department prior to the commencement of construction and/or modification. The following information is required for, and should be submitted with, the application: (1) Engineering report. A report from a qualified engineer or engineering firm, which shall include: a. A scaled plan and elevation view, including a cross section and elevation, supporting drawings, calculations, documentation showing the location and dimensions of the structure, all improvements, and appurtenances associated therewith, including information concerning antenna support structure specifications, antenna locations, equipment facilities, topography, radio frequency coverage, projected power density, and tower height requirements. b. Documentation of the height above grade for potential mounting positions for collocated antennas and the minimum separation distances between antennas. c. Description of the facility's capacity and power density, including the number and type of antennas that it can accommodate. d. Documentation of the structural integrity of the antenna support structure, as set forth in section 44-7(d). The applicant may satisfy the requirements of this subsection by submitting the manufacturer's detailed plans and specifications along with the manufacturer's certification that the telecommunications structure has been constructed according to those plans and specifications, provided the manufacturer's plans and specifications comply with the requirements set forth in section 44-7(d). (2) Site plan. The applicant shall submit a diagram or map which provides a description of the environment surrounding the proposed telecommunications facility and which illustrates the visual impact of the proposed facility. The site plan submitted by the applicant shall be to scale and include: north arrow, location of facility on site, topography of site, setbacks, height of structure, equipment facilities, access to site, adjacent roads, parking, fences, landscaped areas, and adjacent property uses. The site plan may include photo simulations, drawings, or the like of the proposed facility from affected agricultural, residential, commercial properties, structures and sites of historical significance, and rights-of-way at distances of 500 feet and 1,500 feet. (3) Architectural designs. The applicant shall demonstrate that the proposed facility is architecturally designed to blend in with the surrounding environment. In this regard, ground mounted equipment shall be screened from view by suitable vegetation, except where a design of nonvegetative screening better reflects and complements the architectural character of the surrounding neighborhood. (4) Site landscaping design and maintenance. The applicant shall submit a site landscaping and maintenance plan as set forth in section 44-7(g). (5) Geographic coverage description of site location. The applicant shall provide a general description of the geographic area for which the telecommunications facility will provide coverage. (6) Air navigation information. Air navigation information to include all private and public airfields, landing strips and runways within a five mile radius of the proposed site. In the alternative, applicant shall certify that it has conducted an aeronautical study on the navigable airspace within a five-mile radius of the proposed site. (7) Statement of security fencing. The applicant shall submit a security fencing plan as set forth in section 44-7(h). (8) Certificate of insurance. Applicant must produce a certificate of insurance demonstrating protection against claims for bodily injury, personal injury, and property damage in amounts not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $2,000,000.00 annual aggregate. (9) Inventory of existing sites. Each application shall include a site inventory including a list and a map showing all the applicant's existing telecommunications facility sites within the county and within one mile of the county's boundaries in those counties adjacent to the county. The list shall include the following information for each such site: a. Street address; b. Land lot, section district, and parcel number; c. Zoning district; d. Type of building, if applicable (commercial, residential, mixed use), and number of stories; e. The location and type of tower/antenna installation (stand-alone rooftop, building facade, lattice tower, monopole, etc.); f. The location of the base transceiver station installations; g. The height from grade to the top of the antenna installation; h. The radio frequency range in megahertz; i. All other telecommunication facility sites within 2,000 feet of the proposed location. (10) Preferred/disfavored location status. The applicant shall indicate in which location site, as identified in section 44-4(a), the proposed facility will be located. If the proposed location is not to be located in a preferred location as defined in section 44-4(a)(1), the applicant shall provide an explanation of how and why the proposed site is essential to meet service demand for the geographic service area and countywide network. (11) Favored/disfavored structure status. The applicant shall indicate which type of antenna support structure, as identified in section 44-4(b), the proposed facility will utilize. If the proposed antenna support structure is not a favored antenna support structure, as defined in section 44-4(a)(1), the applicant shall provide an explanation of how and why the proposed antenna support structure is essential to meet service demand for the geographic service area and countywide network. (12) Evidence of collocation efforts. Evidence that the applicant has investigated the possibilities for locating the proposed facility on an existing antenna support structure, the use of stealth technology or alternative antenna support structures, or siting at another location where an equal or more optimal level of coverage can be provided while minimizing visual obtrusiveness. Such evidence shall consist of: a. Certified copies of letters sent to owners of all existing facilities within a five-mile radius of the proposed site, requesting the following information: 1. Antenna support structure height and base elevation above sea level; 2. Existing and planned facility uses; 3. Whether the existing antenna support structure could accommodate the proposed antenna without causing instability or radio frequency interference; and 4. If the proposed antenna cannot be accommodated on an existing antenna support structure, an assessment of whether the existing antenna support structure could be structurally modified, the antenna's transmitters and related equipment could be protected from electromagnetic interference, and a general description of the means and projected cost of shared use of the existing antenna support structure; b. Copies of all responses to the certified letters required in this subsection (a)(12) that are received within 30 days of the mailing date of the certified letter; c. A summary explanation of why the applicant believes the proposed facility cannot be located on an existing antenna support structure; and d. A summary explanation of why the applicant believes that the use of an alternative antenna support structure is not possible. (13) Other required information. a. Applicant's notarized authorization to act on behalf of property owner, if applicable; b. Copy of warranty deed of the subject property; c. Property owner's notarized certification of ownership and zoning compliance; d. Political/financial disclosure statements by owner and applicant; e. Application fee; and f. Any information that is required by other sections of the county zoning ordinance. (b) Permits required for the construction and/or modification of telecommunications facilities. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the construction and/or modification of any telecommunications facility shall require the applicant to obtain both a conditional use permit and a building permit. (c) Exceptions. The following shall require only a building permit: (1) Collocating to an existing antenna support structure, provided the collocation does not increase the height of the existing antenna support structure and the proposed addition otherwise complies with the standards described in this chapter. (2) Modifications of existing antenna support structures so as to accommodate for collocation, provided the modification does not increase the height of the existing antenna support structure and the proposed addition otherwise complies with the standards described in this chapter. (3) A proposed telecommunications facility which utilizes a favored antenna support structure as defined in section 44-4(b)(1) and which will be located on a preferred location site as defined in section 44-4(a)(1). (d) Conditional use permits; procedure. Unless excepted by subsection (c) of this section, an applicant's application, when all required information has been provided and the application is considered complete, shall be forwarded by the building permits department to the county planning commission for consideration, review, and determination by the planning commission in accordance with the standards and procedures set forth in this chapter, and sections 50-297 and 50-328, for determination of whether a conditional use permit shall be granted. (e) Building permit requirements; procedure. Application for a building permit shall be made to the county building permits department and shall include, in addition to that listed under subsection (a) of this section, the following: (1) An itemized list of all equipment cost associated with the proposed telecommunications facility; (2) Written certification from the applicant that the proposed telecommunications facility meets all FAA and FCC standards and regulations; (3) An application fee, as set by the county building permits department; and (4) Any other information required by other sections of the county zoning ordinance for the issuance of a building permit. (f) Criteria for review. The following criteria shall be used by the appropriate reviewing body when making an official decision on an application for the construction, modification, or collocation of a telecommunications facility: (1) Determination of whether the applicant is in conformity with goals set forth in this chapter, the county zoning ordinance, and the comprehensive plan; (2) Determination of whether the applicant has cooperated with other telecommunications providers in collocating additional antennas on antenna support structures and/or on existing buildings provided said proposed collocators have received a telecommunications facility building permit; (3) Determination of whether the applicant meets or exceeds the requirements and/or development standards as set forth in this chapter; (4) A review of all other standards available to the reviewing body as set forth in section 50-297; (5) No permit shall be denied on the basis of the environmental effects of radio frequency emissions to the extent that the telecommunications structure complies with FCC regulations concerning emissions. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.5; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.5) Sec. 44-6. - Special requirements for telecommunications facilities located on public property or public-use structures. In addition to other requirements set forth in this chapter, including those related to obtaining a conditional use permit and a telecommunications facility building permit, a telecommunications provider requesting to place or collocate one or more telecommunications structures on property owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by the board of commissioners shall comply with the following: (1) General requirements. a. The applicant shall obtain adequate liability insurance naming the county as an insured, commit to a lease agreement that includes equitable compensation for the use of public land, and other necessary provisions and safeguards, as deed necessary by the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall establish fees after considering comparable rates in other areas, potential expenses, risks to the county, and other appropriate factors. b. The applicant shall submit a letter of credit, performance bond, or other security acceptable to the board of commissioners to cover the costs of removing the facility in the event the owner of the facility fails to do so. c. The applicant shall agree that upon reasonable notice by way of certified mail to the owner/operator or the registered agent of same, the board of commissioners may require that the applicant, at the applicant's sole expense, remove the facility and return the site to its original condition within 120 days of receipt of such notice. d. The applicant shall reimburse the county for any costs, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney fees, that the county incurs due to the presence of the applicant's facility. e. The applicant shall demonstrate that the telecommunications facility will not interfere with the intended purpose for which the public property is owned. f. The applicant shall demonstrate that the facility will have minimal adverse impact on surrounding private property. (2) Special requirements for facilities located on places of public gathering. The use by telecommunications providers of publicly owned parks, recreational facilities, and places of public gathering brings with it special concerns due to the unique nature of these sites. The placement of telecommunications facilities in such locations shall be allowed only when the following additional requirements are met: a. The county parks and recreation department shall review and make a recommendation to the planning commission and commissioner regarding the locating of the proposed telecommunications facility within the park, and, in reaching a decision to approve or to deny locating at such site, this recommendation must be given great weight by the planning commission and commissioner. b. In no case shall a telecommunications facility be permitted to be located within areas designated conservation or environmentally sensitive unless they are collocated on existing facilities. c. A telecommunications facility may be located in public parks adjacent to residential areas only if the parks are of a sufficient scale and character to accommodate the facility without adverse environmental or visual impact or disruption of normal public use and meets all other applicable requirements of this chapter. d. A telecommunications facility may be located in public parks that are adjacent to an existing area designated for commercial or industrial use and only if the parks are of a sufficient scale and character to accommodate the facilities without adverse environmental or visual impact or disruption of normal public use. e. A telecommunications facility may be located in park maintenance facilities. f. A telecommunications facility shall be sited so as to have the least impact upon views and vistas. g. A telecommunications facility shall be sited so as to have the least impact upon operation, maintenance, enjoyment, and safety in parks. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.6; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.6) Sec. 44-7. - Design standards and building requirements for all telecommunications facilities. (a) Building code, safety standards, and regulatory compliance. (1) Building codes and safety standards. All telecommunications facilities shall be constructed, modified, and maintained in compliance with applicable building codes and the applicable standards for such telecommunications facilities that are published by the FCC, FAA, and/or the Electronic Industries Association (EIA), as those standards may be amended from time to time. (2) Regulatory compliance. All telecommunications facilities shall meet or exceed standards and regulations as may be amended of the FAA, the FCC, and any other agency of the state or federal government with the authority to regulate telecommunications facilities. Owners shall provide certification to the commissioner and the building permits department that each telecommunications antenna support structure and/or facility is in compliance with all applicable federal and state requirements when any new users are added or a new telecommunications facility building permit is sought. Failure to comply with the requirements of this section may result in the facility being deemed abandoned as defined in section 44-9. (3) Safety inspections. Each year after a facility becomes operational, the facility owners/operators shall conduct safety inspections of each antenna support structure and facility in accordance with EIA and FCC standards to ensure structural integrity by qualified, independent engineers licensed to practice in the state. The results of such inspection shall be provided to the commissioner and to the building permit department. Failure to comply with the requirements of this section may result in the facility being deemed abandoned as defined in section 44-9. (b) Setbacks. In agriculture/forestry districts, telecommunication (tower) structures must be set back a minimum of the greater of 100 feet, or 50 percent of the tower height from the right-of-way and nearest property line. In commercial districts, the tower must be set back a minimum of 100 feet from the right-of-way and 20 feet from each property line. (c) Separation requirement. No telecommunications structure over 180 feet in height shall be located within one-quarter of a mile from any existing telecommunications structure that is over 180 feet in height, except where both structures are located or property zoned for industrial or mining purposes, or where such requirement is determined to be a hardship by the county planning commission and/or commissioner. (d) Structural integrity. (1) To ensure the structural integrity of the antenna support structure, the owner of a tower shall ensure that the tower withstands a 100 mile-per-hour wind, one-inch ice load, and is maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable local building codes and the EIA/telecommunications industries standards for steel antenna towers and antenna supporting structures (or equivalent), as amended. (2) If upon inspection, an antenna support structure fails to comply with such codes and standards and constitutes a danger to persons or property, then upon notice being provided to the owner/operator or the registered agent thereof, the owner/operator shall have 30 days upon receipt of such notice to bring such antenna support structure into compliance with such structural standards. If the owner/operator fails to bring the antenna support structure into compliance within said 30 days, the board of commissioners may deem the facility abandoned, as set forth in section 44-9. (e) Design requirements to reduce visual impact. (1) Site location and development shall preserve the preexisting character of the surrounding buildings and land uses and zoning district to the extent possible. (2) Antenna support structures, buildings, and related structures shall be integrated through location, design, materials, colors, textures, screening and landscaping to blend with the existing characteristics of the site to the extent possible. (3) Telecommunications antenna support structures shall either maintain a galvanized steel finish or, subject to any applicable standards of the FAA or other applicable federal or state agency, be painted a neutral color or painted and/or textured so as to reduce visual obtrusiveness. (4) If an antenna is installed on a structure other than an antenna support structure or an alternative antenna support structure, the antenna, and all associated electrical and mechanical equipment, equipment shelter or cabinet, must be of a neutral color identical to, or closely compatible with, the color of the supporting or surrounding structures so as to make the antenna and related equipment as visually unobtrusive as possible. Roof-mounted antennas shall be made visually unobtrusive by screening which may include matching them with existing air conditioning units, stairs, elevator towers, or other background. (5) Where feasible, telecommunications facilities shall be placed directly above, below or incorporated with vertical design elements of a building to assist further camouflage. (6) Whenever practical, new telecommunications facilities shall be designed, engineered, and constructed to facilitate collocation in surplus space by other telecommunications providers on the same facility. (7) Telecommunications facilities shall not be placed in any historic district or in any scenic corridors as designated by the board of commissioners or by any state or federal law or agency. (8) Any equipment shelter or cabinet supporting a telecommunications facility shall be concealed from public view, made compatible with the architecture of the surrounding structures or placed underground. (f) Height restrictions. The maximum heights for all telecommunication structures, regardless of zoning classification of the property on which the structure is located, shall be 250 feet. However, no applicant shall be entitled as a matter of right to erect an antenna support structure that is the maximum allowable height under this chapter; rather, the commissioner, the planning commission, and the building permits department shall consider all relevant factors under the applicable permitting processes, as set forth in this chapter, in determining the maximum allowable height for each proposed antenna support structure. (g) Landscaping and buffer requirements. (1) Existing mature tree growth and natural land forms on the site shall be preserved to the extent feasible; provided, however, that vegetation which caused interference with the antenna or inhibits access to the equipment facility may be trimmed to the extent that access is made available. (2) Landscaping shall effectively screen the view of telecommunications facilities from adjacent public rights-of-way, public property and residential property. Additionally, a perimeter buffer having a depth of at least 50 feet shall be required, with a minimum of one tree per 20 lineal feet of buffer, with a minimum of 50 percent being shade-type trees shall be required for all telecommunications facilities. Retention of existing trees on the site in order to meet these requirements is strongly encouraged. Grass and other ground cover species shall be planted on all areas of the buffer strip required which are not covered by other landscape material. (3) It shall be the responsibility of the facility owner/operator to keep all buffers and landscaping properly maintained in order to fulfill the purpose for which it was established. (4) The planning commission and/or commissioner may waive or modify any of the landscaping requirements where lesser requirements are desirable; for visibility or security purposes; for continued operation of existing bona fide agricultural or forest uses such as farms, nurseries and tree farms; other remote agricultural or rural locations; for placement of an antenna on an existing structure; or for developed heavy industrial areas. (h) Security fencing. All facilities shall be enclosed by decay-resistant security fencing not less than six feet in height and equipped with appropriate anti-climbing devices or other similar protective devices to prevent unauthorized access to the telecommunications facility. By way of example only, a three-stranded barbed wire or rolled razor wire attached to a security fence is an appropriate anti-climbing device. However, the board of commissioners reserves the right to impose stricter measures or waive this requirement, as deemed appropriate. Nothing herein shall prevent fencing which is necessary to meet other requirements of state and federal regulations. (i) Lighting. (1) No illumination is permitted on telecommunications facilities unless: a. Required by the FCC, FAA or other state or federal agency of competent jurisdiction; b.
