Necessary for air traffic safety; or c. An antenna is placed on an alternative antenna support structure or publicly used structure that otherwise requires lighting. (2) Where lighting is required or necessary, the board of commissioners may review and select the available lighting alternative that causes the least disturbance to the surrounding uses and views. (j) Advertising. No advertising of any kind is permitted on telecommunications facilities. (k) Principal, accessory, and joint uses. Accessory structures used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall be allowed but not be used for offices, vehicle storage or other outdoor storage. Mobile or immobile equipment not used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall not be stored or parked on the site of the telecommunications facility. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.7; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.7; Ord. of 11-3-2009(2)) Sec. 44-8. - Variance from standards; board of zoning appeals authority; scope of variance; procedure for variance requests and hearings; approval. (a) Board of zoning appeals. The board of zoning appeals shall have authority to consider and recommend approval of an application for a variance in cases where strict adherence to height, size, separation, or standards other than setbacks for telecommunications facilities are shown by the applicant to cause special difficulties that include one or more than the following: (1) Precludes effective transmission or reception of signals; (2) Results in conditions contrary to the purposes of this chapter; or (3) Creates unnecessary hardship to the landowner and/or telecommunications providers. Said hardships shall be set forth in detail and presented in writing to the board of zoning appeals. (b) Scope of variance. The permissible scope of variances for telecommunications facilities applies to: (1) Maximum height, size, or separation requirements; or (2) Any other development standard, collocation requirement, or other provisions of this chapter, when considered in conjunction with applicant's specific site request, where the board of zoning appeals finds such provisions inconsistent with the purposes of this chapter or contrary to the requirements of the Telecommunications Act. If requested by the board of zoning appeals, the applicant shall set forth the inconsistent chapter provisions and contrary Telecommunications Act requirements in detail and present the same in writing to the board of zoning appeals. (c) Procedure. Requests for a variance and hearings on such requests shall be made in accordance with section 50-261. (d) Findings necessary for approval of a variance request. In addition to the criteria set forth in section 50-260(b), a variance may be granted by the board of zoning appeals for proposed telecommunication facilities or modifications only upon findings that the proposed telecommunications facility: (1) Is the least height and proximity to adjacent properties necessary to provide the coverage by the communications service provider and to achieve the purposes of this chapter; (2) Employs all reasonable measures to provide the visual mitigation that screen the facility from views of adjacent residences or undeveloped residential properties; (3) Will not produce noise, vibration, odors or illumination which will adversely impact other properties in the vicinity; (4) By means of design or location does not present a hazard to adjacent properties; and (5) Does not otherwise result in significant adverse impact on the property on which the facility is located, on other property in the vicinity, or on the community in general. (e) Approval of variance request to be narrowly construed. Approval of a request for a variance shall be narrowly construed and shall be based on an evaluation of the operational needs of the telecommunications provider, alternative locations, and/or the antenna support structure upon which a proposed antenna might be located, and/or the absence of collocation opportunities as shown by the applicant's good faith efforts respecting existing facilities within one-quarter mile of the proposed site. Evidence shall demonstrate that no practical alternative is reasonably available to the applicant as balanced against any detrimental effect on the surrounding properties. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.8; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.8) Sec. 44-9. - Abandonment and removal of telecommunications structures; remedies. A telecommunications facility may be determined to be abandoned because of discontinued use or falling into disrepair or noncompliance with standards set forth in this chapter. The county may seek to have the abandoned telecommunications facility removed regardless of the owner/operator's intent to operate the facility and regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. (1) Abandonment because of discontinued use and removal. a. Abandonment. Any telecommunications facility not operated for a continuous period of 12 months shall be considered abandoned, whether or not the owner or operator intends to make use of it or any part of it. b. Removal. The owner/operator of a telecommunications facility and the owner of the property where the facility is located, if not public property, shall jointly and severally be under a duty to remove the abandoned telecommunications facility. (2) Abandonment because of disrepair or noncompliance and removal. a. Abandonment. In the event a telecommunications facility falls into disrepair or noncompliance with the standards set forth in this chapter, the facility shall be determined to be abandoned if repairs are not affected to restore compliance within 30 days after written notice of noncompliance from the board of commissioners. b. Removal. If after the expiration of the 30-day notice of noncompliance from the board of commissioners no action has been taken by the owner to restore compliance of the facility, the owners/operators of the facility and the property where the facility is located, if not on public property, shall jointly and severally be under a duty to remove the abandoned telecommunications facility. (3) Remedies for abandonment. If such facility is not removed within 60 days of receipt of removal notice from the county, the county may remove such facility and place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal, and the county may pursue any and all legal remedies available to it to insure the abandoned telecommunications facility are removed and to recover of all costs associated with the removal. (4) No waiver by delay. Delay by the county in taking action shall not in any way waive the county's right to take action. (5) Expiration of prior approvals. a. Any proposal to reestablish the telecommunications facility after failure to remedy a disrepair or noncompliance shall be treated as a new application, requiring a new conditional use permit and telecommunications facility building permit, subject to reviews, approvals, permits, and fees as required by this chapter. b. Any construction, modification, collocation, or other activity requiring a telecommunications provider to obtain either a conditional use permit or telecommunications facility building permit, or both, shall be commenced within six months of obtaining such permits. In the event the permitted activity is not commenced within such time, the permits shall be deemed expired and the applicant shall be required to obtain new permits as required in section 44-5. (6) Liability for noncompliance. No time period stated herein shall relieve the owner of a telecommunications facility from responsibility to maintain a safe facility. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.9; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.9) Sec. 44-10. - Preexisting telecommunications facilities; definition; rules. (a) Definitions. A preexisting telecommunications facility is a telecommunications facility which exists on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. (b) Rules for preexisting telecommunications facilities. A preexisting telecommunications facility is subject to the following: (1) The preexisting telecommunications structure may continue in use for the purpose then used, but may not be expanded or modified in any manner without complying with this chapter. (2) The preexisting telecommunications facility may add additional antennas and equipment facilities, subject to all other conditions and requirements of this chapter. (3) A preexisting telecommunications facility that is hereafter damaged or destroyed due to any reason or cause may be repaired and restored to its former use, location, and physical dimensions, subject to obtaining a new telecommunications facility building permit as described herein. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.10; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.10) Sec. 44-11. - Penalty for violation of chapter. (a) Any person who erects or attempts to erect a telecommunications facility covered by this chapter without having first obtained the necessary permit or variance in the manner provided in this chapter, or fails to remedy in a timely manner a facility that is in disrepair or noncompliance with this chapter, shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. Any responsible party or other persons convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-13. (b) If any facility is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained in violation of this chapter or without obtaining that required permits, or if any building, structure or land is used in violation of this chapter, the county, in addition to any other remedies, may institute proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use or to correct or abate such violations. Each and every day such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use continues may be deemed a separate offense. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.11; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.11) Sec. 44-12. - Coordination with federal law. Whenever the board of commissioners finds that the application of this chapter would unreasonably discriminate among providers of functionally equivalent personal wireless services or prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting the provision of telecommunications services, a conditional use permit waiving any or all of the provisions of this chapter may be granted. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.12; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.12) Sec. 44-13. - Coordination with zoning ordinance. Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, no conditional use permit, building permit, or variance granted under this chapter shall be transferable from the individual and/or entity to whom said permit or variance was granted at any time prior to the completion of the telecommunications facility for which said conditional use permit or variance was granted. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.13; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, § 17.13) Sec. 44-14. - Availability to public. One copy of this chapter shall be available in the office of the county clerk for use and examination by the public. (Res. of 7-29-2002, § 17.13; Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. XVII, §§ 17.13.1, 17.13.2) Sec. 44-15. - Regulation of basic service tier rates and related equipment, installation and service charges of any cable television system operating in the county. (a) The county will follow the FCC rate regulations in its regulation of the basic service rates and charges of the companies and any other cable television system operating in the county, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions in the franchises. (b) In connection with such regulation, the county will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties. (c) The commissioner or his designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the county and file with FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC rate regulations in order to enable the county to regulate basic service rates and charges. (Ord. of 12-7-1993)

div.head: Chapter 46 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; off-road vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; use of speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 46-1—46-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 46-19. - Adoption of state law. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., known as the uniform rules of the road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the county with like effect as if recited in this article. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 1) Sec. 46-20. - Parental responsibility. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 16 years to permit, whether knowingly or through ineffective control or supervision, such minor to violate any provision of this article or state law regarding the operation of vehicles. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 2) Sec. 46-21. - Temporary traffic regulations. In cases where traffic upon the roads of the county may become congested upon occasions of parades and at theaters and other public assemblages where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the sheriff may make temporary rules directing and regulating the traffic in these congested districts, and any person, who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations, shall violate them, shall be liable therefor as for other violations of this Code. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 3) Sec. 46-22. - Authorized emergency vehicles. (a) The driver of any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section but subject to the conditions herein stated. (b) The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of and said vehicle while in motion sounds audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle. (c) This section shall not be construed to relieve the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. (d) Subject to the foregoing limitations, the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: (1) Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of this chapter; (2) Proceed past a traffic light or stop sign, but only slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; (3) Exceed the speed limits specified so long as he does not endanger life or property; (4) Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. Secs. 46-23—46-47. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES
Sec. 46-48. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Off-road vehicle means, unless the context otherwise requires, any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland, or other natural terrain and not intended for use predominantly on public roads. (1) The term "off-road vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, four-wheel-drive or low-pressure-tire vehicles, two-wheel vehicles (including trail bikes and mini-bikes), amphibious machines, ground effect or air-cushion vehicles, and any other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind. (2) The term "off-road vehicle" does not include any motorboards; any military, fire, or law enforcement vehicles; any vehicles used exclusively on airports; any farm machinery, farm tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land for planting, for utility service and maintenance, for earth moving, construction or mining; or any selfpropelled lawnmowers, snow blowers, garden or lawn tractors, or golf carts while such vehicles are being used exclusively for their designed purposes. Private property means any property owned by any private individual, business or corporation or any private utility corporation. Public property means any property owned by the federal or state government, including any of their political subdivisions or agencies or any public utility company. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 4) Sec. 46-49. - Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an off-road vehicle: (1) Without operative brakes; (2) Without operative mufflers or other silencing equipment; (3) In such a manner as to make, continue to make or cause to be made any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which endangers the comfort, repose, health peace or safety of other citizens and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 50 feet from the point of origin of such sound or noise; (4) On any private property or public property without the owner of the property being present or without the express written permission of the owner; (5) Upon any roadway, street, avenue, highway, public thruway, and/or right-of-way of any street or highway of the state or the county, including those rights-of-way regulated by the state's uniform rules of the road. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 4) Sec. 46-50. - Penalties and impoundment. (a) Any violation of this article shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-13. (b) Each action or activity committed in violation of this article is deemed a separate offense. (c) In addition to the penalties in subsection (a) of this section, any violation of this article is hereby deemed to be a continuing nuisance, and may be abated by an application for injunction or other proceedings allowed by law in the appropriate court. (d) Any off-road vehicle found to be operated in violation of this article may, at the discretion of the deputy marshal, deputy sheriff, or other duly authorized law enforcement officer, be impounded at the vehicle owner's/operator's expense. (Ord. of 5-2-2006, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 48 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Public utilities generally, O.C.G.A. § 46-1-1 et seq.; water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.; public water systems, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-170 et seq.; water supply, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-470; sewage and waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-29 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 48-1. - Utility accommodations program. The county has adopted the state department of transportation's accommodation policy and standards for installation of utilities within the county. (Res. of 12-19-2001) Sec. 48-2. - Damage to public utility property. (a) Damage to utility prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp, or other apparatus belonging to the county. (b) Unauthorized use or theft of utility services prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied, to divert any county utility, or to otherwise intentionally and without authority use or cause to be used, without the consent of the county, any county utility service. (c) Presumption of guilt. Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section and the person who, with knowledge of such violation, receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of the improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for the act of tampering or diversion. (d) Enforcement authority. The county sheriff's department, marshal's office, and health department shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section. (e) Applicable state law; alternative prosecutions. This section shall be cumulative with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. The officials charged with enforcement of this section shall have the discretion to prosecute violations of the provisions of this section either under this section or under state law. Secs. 48-3—48-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 48-31—48-48. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR WATER USE RESTRICTIONS
Sec. 48-49. - Authority and purpose. The county, under its powers pursuant to state law, has adopted this article to protect the public health and welfare. This article implements the county's authority to impose water use restrictions, conditioned upon a restricted water use period declared by the county pursuant to the terms of this article or a declared drought response level implementation declared by the state pursuant to chapter 391-3-30 of the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, entitled "Outdoor Water Use" (Ga. Admin. Code § 391-3-30-.01 et seq.). Sec. 48-50. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Address means the house number (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. Declared drought response level (DDRL) means one of four levels of drought that may be declared by the state department of natural resources based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe, as provided in Ga. Admin. Code § 391-3-30-.01 et seq. (outdoor water use). Even-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. Odd-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. Outdoor watering means any watering of decorative lawns, trees, or shrubbery by water users. Water users means all persons or entities using water from any public water source irrespective of that person's responsibility for billing purposes for use of the water. Sec. 48-51. - Issuance of written warnings to violators. Persons violating water use restrictions as provided herein shall be given one warning in writing prior to the issuance of a citation, unless: (1) The period of restricted water use is declared in response to a DDRL imposed by the state and applicable in the geographical limits of the county; or (2) The declaration of a period of restricted water use specifically provides that no warnings will be given. Sec. 48-52. - Penalties. When a mandatory, total ban on all outdoor water usage is implemented, the following penalties or discontinuance of service shall apply to violators of the water usage ban:
(Res. of 9-7-1999) Sec. 48-53. - Declaration of period of restricted water use. The board of commissioners shall declare a period of restricted water use in either of two circumstances: (1) State DDRL announcement. In the event of imposition by the state department of natural resources of a DDRL encompassing the geographical area of the county or any part thereof, the board of commissioners shall declare a water emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this article shall apply to all water use within the county until the restrictions are lifted by the board of commissioners; provided, however, that the restrictions shall remain in full force and effect until any state outdoor watering ban has been lifted. (2) Local declaration. In the event of prolonged drought, failure of equipment, or any other factor that substantially affects or may affect the supply of water to the county and the county's water users, the board of commissioners may declare an emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this article shall apply to all water use within the county until the restrictions are lifted. The declaration should be, where appropriate, conditioned on the identification of an emergency or water shortage by the county personnel, state agency, federal agency, or the governor of the state. Sec. 48-54. - Notice of declaration. Upon declaration of a period of restricted water use, the board of commissioners shall notify all users through news releases to the media, through notices mailed to all users, or through such other means as the board of commissioners shall deem expedient and appropriate. Notice shall be given as soon as practical after the declaration of a period of restricted water use is made. Sec. 48-55. - Watering methods. During a period of restricted water use of any level, outdoor watering is restricted to bucket, can, or handheld hose watering with automatic shutoff nozzle. The use of automatic sprinkler systems is prohibited, except watering of newly installed landscaping as permitted herein and except testing of a newly installed or newly repaired sprinkler system by a commercial enterprise engaged in the installation or repair of lawn irrigation systems. Sec. 48-56. - Level One restrictions. In the event of declaration of a Level One period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the county: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight; (2) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays; (3) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays; (4) Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. Sec. 48-57. - Level Two restrictions. In the event of declaration of a Level Two period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the county: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m.; (2) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays; (3) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays. (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing; b. Washing hard surfaces such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. Sec. 48-58. - Level Three restrictions. In the event of declaration of a Level Three period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the county: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m.; (2) The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday; (3) The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday; (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing; b. Washing hard surfaces such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety; c. Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity; d. Washing vehicles such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, and golf carts; e. Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection; f. Noncommercial fund-raisers, such as carwashes; g. Using water for ornamental purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. Sec. 48-59. - Level Four restrictions. In the event of declaration of a Level Four period of restricted water use, no outdoor water use is permitted, unless the use is exempted under the provisions of this article or specifically by the board of commissioners or county manager. Sec. 48-60. - Exemptions. The following uses are exempt from the use restrictions of this article unless the board of commissioners or county manager, at the time of declaration of a period of restricted water use, shall specifically designate one or more of the exemptions inapplicable, and provided that in exercising an exemption water use conservation practices should be implemented wherever possible: (1) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical code adopted by the county; (2) Reuse of gray water in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical codes adopted by the county; (3) Use of reclaimed wastewater for landscaping purposes by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater; (4) Irrigation of personal food gardens; (5) Except during Level Four restrictions, irrigation of landscapes that have been installed for less than 30 days and by persons who are not certified or licensed professionals, any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the restriction level in effect, and then only for a period of 30 days following installation; (6) For golf courses, use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater, irrigation of fairways during times of nondrought and Level One restrictions, irrigation of tees during times of nondrought and Level One, Two, or Three restrictions, and irrigation of greens; (7) Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers, but during installation and 30 days following installation only; (8) Irrigation contractors, but during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only; (9) Sod producers, ornamental growers, fruit and vegetable growers, retail garden center, hydro-seeding, power washing, construction sites, producers of food and fiber, and carwashes; (10) Water in of pesticides and herbicides on turf; (11) Use of water for firefighting, health, sanitation, and medical purposes; and (12) Other activities essential to daily business. Sec. 48-61. - Application for waiver. Any water user that considers the restrictions imposed during a period of restricted water use to adversely affect his livelihood, health, or sanitation, may make written application for a waiver. Any such application should be directed to the attention of the board of commissioners which shall make a determination regarding waiver within five business days of receipt of the application. The determination of the board of commissioners shall be final. Secs. 48-62—48-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWER
Sec. 48-81. - State administrative regulations applicable. The installation and maintenance of an individual sewage disposal system in the county shall conform to Ga. Comp. R. and Regs. §§ 290-5-25 et seq. and 290-5-26 et seq. (on-site sewage management systems). (Res. of 7-11-1989, § 1) Sec. 48-82. - Minimum standards. In addition to state regulations referenced in section 48-81, any owner, developer, lessee, or agent thereof of every building, residence or other structure which will not be served by a public sewerage system shall conform to the following minimum standards: (1) Single-family dwelling units . Building lots for single-family detached dwelling units shall be the greater of one-half acre or sufficient acreage to provide 8,000 square feet of useable land for individual sewage disposal exclusive of that area occupied or to be occupied by structures, paving, parking areas, driveways, and in-ground utilities; provided further, there shall not be more than one single-family detached dwelling unit allowed on said lot. Single-family dwelling unit includes, but is not limited to, conventional housing, industrialized buildings, and manufactured housing. (2) Duplexes . Building lots for duplexes shall be the greater of three-fourths of an acre or sufficient acreage to provide 10,000 square feet of useable land for sewage disposal exclusive of that area occupied or to be occupied by structures, paving, parking areas, driveways, and in-ground utilities. (3) Apartments, condominiums, and all other residential dwelling structures . Building lots for three or more attached residential dwelling units shall be the greater of one acre or of sufficient acreage to provide 2,000 square feet of useable land per bedroom for sewage disposal exclusive of that area occupied or to be occupied by structures, paving, parking areas, driveways, and in-ground utilities. (4) Minimum length of nitrification line . Every dwelling unit shall have a minimum of 250 square feet of nitrification line per bedroom. (5) Building lot width. No building lot shall be less than 100 feet in width. (6) Percolation tests . Percolation tests and/or other soil interpretative date deemed necessary by the board of commissioners shall be required prior to the development of any lot in the county on which a residential dwelling unit is to be placed. Installation of an individual sewage disposal system shall not commence until such time as a certificate of compliance with these rules and regulations has been obtained from the county department of health. (7) Mobile home parks . Mobile home parks served by public or community water systems but where individual on-site sewage management systems are used for individual spaces shall be limited to a density of not more than five spaces per acre; provided that whenever possible, mobile home parks should be served by a central or community sewage system. (8) Individual water and sewage systems . Whenever a structure is to be served by both an individual water system and an individual on-site sewage management system, the minimum lot sizes set out herein shall be increased in size by 50 percent. (Res. of 7-11-1989, § 2) Sec. 48-83. - Applicability. The rules and regulations contained herein shall be binding upon any and all properties upon which there was not located a structure to which these rules and regulations apply as of July 11, 1989. (Res. of 7-11-1989, § 2) Sec. 48-84. - Enforcement of more stringent standards. Nothing contained in this article is to be interpreted as prohibiting the enforcement of any other rules and regulations now or hereafter adopted which set forth more stringent standards than are contained herein or the taking of any appropriate action to enforce the health laws of this state against any existing structure which may be found to be in violation of said health laws. (Res. of 7-11-1989, § 2) Sec. 48-85. - Penalty. Any person violating the terms of this article shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-13. In addition, any violation of this article is hereby deemed to be a continuing nuisance and may be abated by an application for injunction in the superior court of the county or other court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. of 8-7-1990(2), § 1-5) Sec. 48-86. - Enforcement. (a) Upon information being made known to the health officer, his designee, or the county attorney, there shall cause a citation to be issued requiring said violator to appear before the judge of the magistrate court on a day and time certain, then and there to stand trial for violation of this regulation. (b) Citations issued hereunder shall be pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63 and shall be personally served upon the person accused. Each citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial. (Ord. of 8-7-1990(2), § 1-4) Sec. 48-87. - Fees; hardship waivers. (a) There shall be a service fee for activities in conjunction with the permitting and inspection of on-site sewage management systems in the amount established by the board of commissioners. (b) A schedule of fees relative to on-site sewage activities shall be proposed annually by the county health board and approved by the local governing authority. Fees shall be payable upon receipt of construction permits. (c) For instances where the collection of fees impose a justifiable hardship, affected parties may present documentation to the county board of health and request a waiver of said fees. Service will not be denied because of a client's inability to pay. (Ord. of 8-7-1990(2), amend.)

div.head: Chapter 50 - ZONING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflict of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; county and municipal planning, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 50-1. - Preamble and enactment clause. The board of commissioners, pursuant to Ga. Const. art. IX, § 2, ¶ 4, hereby ordains and enacts into law the articles and sections contained in this chapter. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. I) Sec. 50-2. - Short title. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Haralson County, Georgia, Zoning Ordinance." (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. II) Sec. 50-3. - Interpretation of certain terms and words. For the purpose of interpreting this chapter, certain words or terms used herein shall be defined as follows: (1) Words used in the present tense include the future tense. (2) Words used in the singular number include the plural, and words used in the plural include the singular. (3) The term "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, corporation, trust, and company as well as an individual. (4) The term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel." (5) The term "building" includes the term "structure." (6) The term "shall" is always mandatory. (7) Except in the context of section 50-91 on nonconforming uses, the term "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the terms "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." (8) The term "maps," "zoning map," or "Haralson County Zoning Map" means the "Official Zoning Maps of Haralson County, Georgia." (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. III(3.1)) Sec. 50-4. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accessory use means a use customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or building and located on the same lot with such principal use or building. Agriculture means the raising of soil crops and livestock in a customary manner on tracts of land at least five acres in size and shall include all customary associated activities. Retail selling of products raised on the premises shall be considered a permissible activity, provided that space necessary for the parking of customers' vehicles shall be provided off the public rights-of-way. Alley means a minor way, public or private, used for service access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting a street. Barn means an enclosed structure that is designed or used at any time to house more than three farm animals weighing in excess of 85 pounds each or more than six farm animals of any size. Block means a piece or parcel of land entirely surrounded by public highways or streets, other than alleys. Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or by walls and intended for shelter, housing, or enclosure of persons and or moveable property. Building, accessory means a detached structure designed for the use of which is clearly incidental to and subordinate to the principal structure or use of the land which is located on the same lot as the principal structure or use, and is not to be used for temporary or permanent living quarters. Building, principal means a building in which is conducted the main use of the lot on which said building is located. Clustering means, instead of the conventional design method of distributing substantially identically sized lots across the entire area of a subdivision, the same total number of lots, most being of smaller acreage than would normally be permitted in that zoning district, are grouped fronting existing public rights-of-way and upon environmentally less sensitive areas. The remaining oversized parcel or parcels, frequently flag lots, shall be designated as permanent conservation easements, and the open space thus created is never again eligible for further subdivision or rezoning. Commissioner means in instances where these ordinances read commissioner or Haralson County Commissioner, it is intended to mean board of commissioners. Conditional uses means a use not ordinarily permitted within a given zoning district but which may be permitted upon the imposition of conditions related to the promotion of the public health, safety, morals or general welfare and designed to minimize the negative impact on surrounding lands. A conditional use must be approved in the same manner as a rezoning request prior to the issuance of a permit. Conditional zoning means the imposition of conditions in the grant of a rezoning application which are in addition to or different from the regulations set forth in this chapter and which are related to the promotion of the public health, safety, morals or general welfare and designed to minimize the negative impact on surrounding lands. Such conditions may include, but are not limited to, restrictions on land use, height, setbacks and other non-use requirements, physical improvements to the property and infrastructure serving the property. Condominium means individual ownership units in a multifamily structure, combined with joint ownership of common areas of the building, grounds, in accordance with all applicable provisions of the "Apartment Ownership Act" of 1963 (Ga. Laws 1963, as amended). Development means subdividing a tract of land into two or more lots whether for sale or rental. Diagonal tie means any tiedown designed to resist horizontal or shear forces and that deviates not less than 30 degrees from a vertical point. Dwelling means a building designed, arranged, or used for permanent living quarters for one or more persons. Dwelling unit means a building, or portion thereof, providing complete living facilities for one family. Easement means a grant by a property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person. Family means an individual or two or more persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption living together in a dwelling unit, or a group of not more than four persons who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption, living together in a dwelling unit. For purposes of this chapter, a family may include five or fewer foster children placed in a family foster home licensed by the state, but shall not include fraternities, sororities, roominghouses or boardinghouses, rest homes, tourist homes, group care facilities, or family care homes. Family care home means a use in which domiciliary care is provided with support and supervisory personnel that provide room and board, personal care and rehabilitation services in a family environment for resident persons with disabilities who have physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of such person's major life activities so that such person is incapable of living independently, a record of having such an impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment. However, the term "disability" shall not include: (1) The current illegal use of, or addiction to, either alcohol or a controlled substance; (2) Any person whose residency may constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other individuals or whose tendency would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others; (3) Work-release facilities for convicts or ex-convicts, or other housing facilities serving as an alternative to incarceration; or (4) Persons who are otherwise not deemed to be disabled as that term is defined under the Fair Housing Act, 42 USC § 3601 et seq. Ground anchor means any device at the manufactured house stand designed to secure a manufactured house to the ground. Habitable area means the gross square foot area (measured from the outside of the exterior walls) of the insulated and heated portion of a dwelling unit, and: (1) Having a minimum average framed ceiling height of seven feet, six inches; (2) Having a finished floor elevation averaging not more than 30 inches below the adjacent exterior finished grade; and (3) Each room or space (excluding baths, halls, storage and laundry areas) having an area of exterior light (windows) equaling at least ten percent of that room's floor area, and having ventilation to the exterior of at least five percent of that room's floor area. Home occupation means any occupancy use as defined herein, customarily conducted within the principal dwelling and carried on by the occupant thereof; provided that, such use shall not occupy more than 30 percent of the habitable area; provided further that, such use is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling as a residence and does not change the character thereof or reveal from the exterior that the dwelling is being used in part for other than a residence; provided further that, there is no display, no stock in trade, no commodity sold on the premises, and no mechanical equipment used except such as is commonly used for purely domestic household purposes. Such permissible occupations include, in general, such personal services such as are furnished by a musician, artist, seamstress, cook, academic tutor, or laundress, income tax service, barbershops, beauty parlors, tea rooms, tourist homes, but shall not include such uses as animal hospitals, professional offices, a wholesale, retail or manufacturing business. Industrialized housing means a factory fabricated dwelling or commercial unit built in one or more sections designed to fit together on a permanent foundation but which usually does not originally have wheels for movement and which is constructed in accordance with the Georgia Industrialized Building Act and which bears the seal of approval issued by the commissioner of community affairs. (Includes the term "modular house".) Junkyard means any such use involving the storage or disassembly of wrecked automobiles, trucks, or other vehicles; storage, baling or otherwise dealing in bones, animal hides, scrap metal, commercial/residential appliances, used paper, used cloth, used plumbing fixtures and used brick, wood, or other building materials. Such uses shall be considered junkyards whether or not all or part of such operations are conducted inside a building or in conjunction with, addition to, or accessory to, other uses of the premises. Lot means a developed or undeveloped tract of land in one ownership and legally transferable as a single unit of land. Lot, depth of means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines, measured in the general direction of the side lot lines. Lot, flag means a lot that has narrow frontage on a public right-of-way, has the main body of the lot, the "flag," located away from the public right-of-way, and has less than the minimum lot width normally required at the setback line in that zoning district. The "flag staff," which connects the flag to the public street, shall be 25 feet wide except in cases of extraordinary physical constraint. Flag lots are permitted only to promote clustering and to minimize the additional cost of perpetual road maintenance. Lot, width of means the distance between side lot lines measured at the building line. Manufactured house (mobile home) means a detached, single-family dwelling unit designed for long-term occupancy and constructed in one or more units with wheels for movement (whether or not such wheels are later removed) and which has plumbing and electrical connections provided for long-term attachment to outside systems, whether or not such unit is subsequently installed on a permanent foundation or other internal or external changes are made. Manufactured house, multi-unit, means a detached single-family dwelling unit constructed in two or more units with similar marriage walls with wheels for movement (whether or not such wheels are later removed) and which has plumbing and electrical connections provided for long-term attachment to outside systems, whether or not such unit is subsequently installed on a permanent foundation or other internal or external changes are made. Manufactured house park means a parcel of land which has been planned, improved, and approved for the placement of manufactured houses for nontransient use. Manufactured house stands means that area of a manufactured house lot which has been reserved for the placement of a manufactured house. Nonconforming use means a lawful use of or vested right to use any building, structure, or land existing at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived or the adoption of any amendment thereto. Open space means an area that is not used for or occupied by a driveway, an off-street parking area, a loading space, a yard, a refuse storage space, or a building. Planned unit development (PUD) means a planned development on a minimum of ten acres without regard to the customary lot size requirements or the segregation of housing types or uses and which may include multiple zones within the same tract. Plat means a map, plan, or layout of a county, city, town, lot, section, subdivision, or development indicating the location and boundaries of properties. Principal use means the primary purpose for which land or a building is used. Retail business means a business consisting primarily of buying merchandise or articles in gross and selling to general consumers in small quantities or broken lots or parcels and not in bulk and not for resale. Right-of-way line means the dividing line between a lot, tract, or parcel of land and a contiguous right-of-way. Roominghouse or boardinghouse means a dwelling other than a hotel, lodginghouse, or family-care home where meals or housing accommodations for three or more persons are provided for hire. Sign, business, means an attached or freestanding structure which directs attention to a business or profession conducted on the premises. Sign, outdoor advertising, means any outdoor sign, light, display, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, billboard, or other thing which is designed, intended, or used to advertise or inform any part of the advertising or information contents of which are visible from any place on the main traveled way, interstate, primary highway, or county road. Skirting or underpinning means installation of acceptable material from the exterior base of the manufactured house to the ground which may or may not provide support to the house. Slope means the ratio of rise over run (i.e., 1:4 is one foot of rise in a four-foot run). Southern Standard Building Code means minimum standards as set by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Incorporated, as may be amended from time to time, pertaining to building, fire prevention, gas, mechanical, and plumbing. Stable means any enclosed structure that is designed or used at any time to house more than three horses, so that a stable is a form of barn, as defined herein. Street means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as an avenue, road, boulevard, highway, expressway, lane, alley, or other way. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are divided into the following categories: (1) Alley. The term "alley" means a minor way, public or private, used for service access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. (2) Cul-de-sac. The term "cul-de-sac" means the end of a minor or secondary street which is terminated with a paved turnaround. (3) Dead end. The term "dead end" means a stub street in a subdivision which will at a later time be continued into another portion of the subdivision. (4) Major or arterial streets. The term "major or arterial streets" means those streets designed to serve moderately fast and voluminous traffic through and within the county with a minimum of traffic control devices. (5) Minor or local streets. The term "minor or local streets" means those streets used primarily for access to adjacent and abutting properties. (6) Secondary or collector streets. The term "secondary or collector streets" means those streets designed to collect traffic from minor or local streets and distribute it to major or arterial streets. Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires location on the ground, or attachment to something having location on the ground. Subdivision means a tract of land divided into two or more lots. Swimming pool means any structure intended for swimming or recreational bathing that contains water over 24 inches deep. This includes in-ground, above ground, and on-ground swimming pools. Travel trailer/recreational vehicle means a portable structure, whether self-propelled or pulled by a power unit, designed for temporary occupancy for travel, recreation, or vacation uses. Wholesale business means a business primarily engaged in the selling of goods or articles in gross to retailers or jobbers for resale and not to the ultimate consumer. Yard means an open space on the same lot with a principal building, open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings or structures from ground to sky except where encroachments and accessory buildings are expressly permitted. Yard, front, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot, and situated between the street and the front line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Yard, rear, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and situated between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to side lines of the lot. Yard, side, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, situated between the building and the side lot line of the lot and extending from the front yard to the rear yard. Any lot line not a rear line or a front line shall be deemed a sideline. Zoning administrator means the county building inspector or such other official as the board of commissioners may designate. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. III(3.2); Ord. of 11-3-2009(3); Ord. of 11-3-2009(4)) Sec. 50-5. - Continuance of a nonconforming use (grandfathering). A lawful use of or vested right to use any building, structure, or land existing at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or the adoption of any amendment thereto, may be continued subject to the restrictions contained in this chapter even though such use does not conform with the regulations of this chapter, except that: (1) A nonconforming use or structure shall not be changed to another nonconforming use. (2) A nonconforming use or structure shall not be extended or enlarged beyond the area of use or the size of the structure as it existed on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or the adoption of any amendments thereto. (3) A nonconforming use or structure shall not be re-established after discontinuance for one year regardless of any reservation of intent not to abandon. (4) Any intended nonconforming use for which a vested right was acquired prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or the adoption of an amendment thereto, shall be prohibited unless such intended nonconforming use for which a vested right was acquired is actually commenced within one year of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived or the adoption of an amendment thereto, regardless of the intent or expectation to commence or abandon such nonconforming use. (5) A nonconforming use or structure shall not be rebuilt, altered, relocated, or repaired except as provided herein: a. If the structure is altered or repaired, said alterations or repairs shall be in conformity with the building codes in force at the time of said alteration or repair; provided, however, that said alteration or repair shall not extend or enlarge the structure being altered or repaired. b. If the structure is totally rebuilt, the replacement structure shall conform with all the requirements of this chapter, except as to the district; provided, however, said replacement structure may not occupy an area greater than the replaced structure. (6) For nonconforming manufactured houses, see subsections 50-7(9) and (10). (7) For nonconforming manufactured house parks, see subsection 50-10(12). (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.1) Sec. 50-6. - Individual detached single-family dwellings. (a) Any single-family dwelling shall be constructed or installed so as to comply with the codes currently in effect in the county at the time a permit is issued; provided, however, said dwelling shall contain not less than 800 square feet of habitable area. (b) For construction purposes, a temporary utility connection may be obtained after securing a building permit. Permanent utility installation will be allowed only after the final inspection of the building, approval of the building inspector, and the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (c) Any dwelling which is damaged beyond repair by fire or a natural or manmade disaster shall be removed and disposed of within a time period not to exceed 60 days after said damage occurred. An extension of this time may be approved by the zoning administrator or his designated agent. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.2) Sec. 50-7. - Manufactured and relocated houses. Any dwelling that is classified as a manufactured or relocated home by the definitions of this chapter shall be subject to the following provisions: (1) No manufactured, mobile, or conventional (site built) house or home shall be brought into or located within the county unless: a. Such house or home is ten years old or less (from the date of manufacture or construction), 24 feet wide or greater; and b. The owner of the house or home has been issued a current placement permit by the county department of permits. Once legally located within county, nothing herein shall prohibit the relocation of said house or home regardless of age, provided said house or home meets all requirements and compatibility of the zoning district in which it is placed and is in good habitable condition. A manufactured house or home may not be moved from its present location to be used as a storage unit. (2) Each individual who violates this section shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each separate violation. For purposes of this section, an "individual" includes the owner of the house or home and/or the owner of the property upon which the house or home is placed. (3) Upon written notification from the county marshall and/or code enforcement officer to the individual in violation of this section, such individual shall remove the house or home from the county within 30 days from receipt of the notification; provided, in the event said house or home is not removed from the county within 30 days after receipt of notification to remove, the county may remove the house or home, and the individual in violation of this section shall be jointly and severally responsible to the county for all costs associated with the removal; provided further, nothing herein shall be construed so as to create an affirmative duty on the county to remove said house or home. (4) Each individual who, within 30 days of receiving notification from the county marshal and/or code enforcement officer that he is in violation of this section, fails to remove said house or home from the county shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each separate violation and/or six months in jail. For purposes of this section, upon expiration of the 30 days set forth in this section, each day a house or home that is in violation of this section remains within the county shall constitute a separate violation. (5) Notwithstanding sections 50-59 and 50-6(a), all new placements of single-family manufactured houses in the county shall meet or exceed the requirements of the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) set forth in 24 CFR, parts 3280 and 3282, as promulgated pursuant to the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401 et seq. All new placements of manufactured houses within the residential, forestry, or agricultural districts of the county shall additionally have siding materials consisting of wood, vinyl, hardboard, stucco, brick, stone, or other siding materials commonly available for residential construction. All such manufactured houses shall additionally possess a roof pitch sufficient to meet the materials and engineering requirements for construction allowed by HUD, and shall contain underpinning. Manufactured houses placed on individual lots within the residential, forestry, or agricultural zoning districts of the county shall contain habitable area equaling the greater of 1,000 square feet or the minimum habitable area required within that zoning district. (6) All manufactured house installations, whether a new location or relocation, must meet applicable manufacturer's installation instructions as required by O.C.G.A. § 8-2-165 and applicable requirements and rules adopted by the state fire safety commissioner pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160 et seq. Final approval of temporary utility connections will occur only following final installation arrangements. (7) All manufactured houses henceforth brought into or relocated within the county not only shall be supported by poured concrete piers or a continuous poured concrete foundation but also shall have underpinning. In the event any manufactured house presently located in a manufactured house park, as defined in section 50-4, is relocated, the owner shall have 30 days from the date of a relocation permit to provide the foundation and underpinning in accordance with this section. Underpinning for manufactured houses located within a manufactured house park shall consist of one of the following: vinyl siding or panels, aluminum siding or panels, or such other material as may be approved by the zoning administrator prior to installation. Underpinning for manufactured houses not located within a manufactured house park shall consist of permanent masonry only. The following types of materials are not permitted for underpinning, including but not limited to: tin, plastic sheeting, gypsum board (flat board), or wood, unless the wood is of a type that is naturally resistant to decay, such as cedar. The underpinning must be adequately secured to the manufactured house. Where required to meet manufacturers' specifications for installation and tie down, the underpinning must be secured to the ground. Ventilation for the area beneath the manufactured house shall be adequate, and access to the area beneath the house in a manner adequate to allow inspection and maintenance shall be provided. (8) All construction of additions to manufactured houses placed in the county which are commenced after the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall require a building permit. Prior to the time the building permit is issued, the county zoning administrator is required to review the building permit application and the materials submitted therewith to ensure that the additions comply with the provisions of this chapter. (9) All manufactured house installations shall provide an adequate means of entry to the house. (10) A manufactured house used for a commercial or industrial sales office shall comply with the provisions of this chapter pertaining to installation. Use of manufactured houses used for commercial or industrial sales offices for living purposes is prohibited. (11) All manufactured houses used temporarily during construction must be licensed as a temporary construction structure and must be permitted for construction use and temporary placement by the zoning administrator. Manufactured houses used for construction shall not remain at any one site beyond the duration of the construction project for which the units are used, or the expiration of 12 months, whichever is greater, unless approved as being in compliance with this chapter by the zoning administrator. (12) A nonconforming manufactured house may continue to be used and occupied until any one of the following events occurs: a. Such manufactured house is moved from its present site; b. Such manufactured house is damaged to such extent that the cost of repair would exceed 50 percent of the replacement cost of the manufactured house; c. Such manufactured house remains unoccupied for a continuous period of six months, unless such period is extended by the zoning administrator for good cause shown; or d. Such manufactured house is declared to be nonhabitable by appropriate public health authorities. (13) In the event that any nonconforming manufactured house is or becomes a nuisance or health hazard, or endangers the health and welfare of the citizens of the county, the zoning administrator may, by and through the appropriate county governmental officials, take appropriate legal action to have said nonconforming manufactured house removed or to remedy the problems caused by said nonconforming manufactured house. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.3) Sec. 50-8. - Junkyards. Any existing junkyard which is a legitimate nonconforming use under this chapter shall comply with the buffer provisions of section 50-15(7) within one year of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.4) Sec. 50-9. - Travel trailer/recreational vehicles parks or campgrounds. Travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks or campgrounds shall only be located in A-1 or F-1 districts, as a conditional use, and shall not be occupied as a dwelling. No tent, travel trailer, or recreational vehicle shall be occupied as a dwelling except as provided in article VII of this chapter. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.5) Sec. 50-10. - Manufactured house parks. Manufactured house parks as defined in this chapter must adhere to the following conditions: (1) No manufactured house park shall be constructed or maintained on a lot with a total area of less than ten acres, or having an average width of less than 400 feet. This ten-acre minimum must be adhered to throughout the existence of the manufactured house park. (2) Each manufactured house space shall be at least 80 feet in width and shall provide a minimum of 12,000 square feet. In cul-de-sac or curved street design, the width of the manufactured house space shall be at least 80 feet at the location of the center of the manufactured house unit. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the maximum density of units on each acre of any park shall not exceed three units in areas served by both public sewer and water. Density in manufactured house parks using either private water or individual septic facilities shall be governed by local and state health regulations but shall not exceed the requirements of section 50-111(1). (3) Notwithstanding sections 50-59 and 50-7(1), a manufactured house shall be allowed in any manufactured house park in the county so long as it: a. Is not more than ten years old; b. Contains not less than 800 square feet of habitable living area; and c. Is constructed in conformity with the requirements of the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974. (4) A minimum of ten percent of the total usable and unconstrained area of any park shall be set aside and designated for recreational purposes. (5) Convenience establishments of a commercial nature, including stores, pickup laundry and dry cleaning agencies, and beauty shops and barbershops may be permitted in manufactured housing parks, provided that such establishments and the parking areas primarily related to their operations are adequate and approved by the zoning administrator, and they: a. Occupy not more than ten percent of the areas of the park; b. Are subordinated to the residential use and character of the park; and c. Are located, designed, and intended to serve frequent trade or service needs of persons residing in the park only. (6) The manufactured house park site plan, including recreational and convenience establishment, shall be, at the time of application, accompanied by a certificate of approval from the county health department and submitted to the county zoning administrator for approval. (7) Each manufactured house site shall be provided with drives connecting with the interior drive and sufficient space to provide at a minimum two off-street parking spaces. In addition, driveways at least 18 feet wide shall be provided to service buildings. Streets are required to be constructed according to minimum requirements provided in this chapter (except curbing and dedication of streets). Furthermore, in front of each unit and within 20 feet of the pavement edge, each dwelling unit shall prominently and uniformly display its address with reflective letters and numbers. (8) One refuse collection station shall be provided for each 20 families or fraction thereof. It shall be conveniently located for collection not more than 200 feet from any manufactured house served. If individual refuse containers are used on manufactured house sites, stands must be provided to hold the cans and screen them from public view. (9) Each manufactured house park shall be landscaped with trees and fast-growing screen planting so as to complement the development and surrounding areas. (10) No manufactured house shall be located within ten feet of its individual lot line or 40 feet from any public road right-of-way. (11) A buffer strip at least 25 feet wide shall be located adjacent to each exterior property line of the manufactured house park and shall not be included within any individual manufactured house lot. This buffer strip shall be increased to a width of 50 feet when located adjacent to single-family residences. This strip shall be densely planted with fast-growing evergreen shrubs or trees. (12) Existing manufactured house parks shall be brought into conformity with all of the requirements and provisions of this chapter within five years from the original effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, December 2004. Any additions to existing manufactured house parks and any replacement or improvements thereto made after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall fully comply therewith. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.6) Sec. 50-11. - Detached single-family developments. Detached single-family developments as defined in this chapter must adhere to the following conditions: (1) The developer/subdivider of any subdivision shall provide adequate streets and shall pave said streets according to minimum requirements as provided in this chapter; provided, that any proposed development which shall be entirely located along a public road, such that said public road serves as the sole road from which access to each lot is gained, shall prior to approval agree to and submit plans to make all improvements of such public road as is, in the opinion of the director of roads, the zoning administrator, the planning commission, and/or the board of commissioners, necessary to avoid and prevent hazard or danger to the public. (2) On any development of three acres or more and comprised of more than four lots, a soil survey prepared by a soil scientist registered in the state shall be submitted with an application for rezoning or subdivision approval. (3) A permit must be obtained from the county public works department for any street or driveway entering a county road. The permit for a driveway must be obtained before a building permit will be issued except where curb cut and gutter has been previously installed. (4) A temporary construction exit must be installed and maintained while construction and/or grading equipment will be leaving a construction site to a public right-of-way, street, or parking area until construction is completed. The construction exit may be the same as the driveway exit. a. The temporary construction exit pad shall be adequate to substantially eliminate the transport of mud from the construction site by either motor vehicles and equipment or from water run-off. b. Any materials or mud spilled, dropped, washed, or tracked from vehicles or from the site onto roadways or into storm drains must be removed within 24 hours or the county may perform any necessary corrective work and the owner/developer shall reimburse the county for any expenses incurred. In the event the county undertakes the corrective work, neither building permits nor certificates of occupancy for said development shall be issued until said expenses have been reimbursed to the county. c. The exit pad of gravel or stone must at least be 12 feet in width by 20 feet in length with a depth of four inches. The pad may be required to be an additional width, length, and/or depth if, in the opinion of the public works department, conditions so warrant. d. In addition, all construction sites must comply with chapter 16, article VI of this Code. (5) A developer may construct a single-family subdivision in which the streets contained therein are not dedicated to the county only upon compliance with all of the following: a. All provisions of this chapter shall apply to the development of said subdivision except section 50-12(3)i, which provides for the streets to be dedicated to the county; b. There shall be only one entrance/exit from the subdivision to a public street. In no event shall a private street be constructed so as to permit said street, in any configuration, to serve as a connecting street between two public streets. Other than the entrance/exit to the private subdivision, no private street shall adjoin any property outside the limits of the private subdivision; c. The plat of the subdivision shall reflect and reserve all necessary utility easements and private rights-of-way to service the subdivision; d. All plats shall be labeled as a "private subdivision" and shall contain on the face thereof the following language in prominent bold capital letters: "THE STREETS IN THIS SUBDIVISION ARE PRIVATE STREETS AND ARE NEITHER MAINTAINED BY HARALSON COUNTY NOR CONSIDERED PART OF THE ROAD SYSTEM OF HARALSON COUNTY. THE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE UPKEEP AND MAINTENANCE OF THE STREETS SHOWN HEREON ARE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE INDIVIDUAL HOMEOWNERS THROUGH THE SUBDIVISION'S INCORPORATED HOMEOWNER'S ASSOCIATION"; e. All deeds of conveyance for individual lots shall contain on the face thereof the following language in prominent bold capital letters: "THE GRANTEE HEREIN ACKNOWLEDGES THAT ANY AND ALL MEANS OF INGRESS AND EGRESS TO THE PROPERTY CONVEYED HEREIN ALONG THE STREETS OF THE SUBDIVISION AS OUTLINED ON THE PLAT OF SAID SUBDIVISION ARE PRIVATE STREETS AND ARE NEITHER MAINTAINED BY HARALSON COUNTY NOR CONSIDERED PART OF THE ROAD SYSTEM OF HARALSON COUNTY. THE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE UPKEEP AND MAINTENANCE OF THE STREETS SHOWN THEREON ARE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE INDIVIDUAL HOMEOWNERS THROUGH THE SUBDIVISION'S INCORPORATED HOMEOWNER'S ASSOCIATION AND NOT HARALSON COUNTY"; f. The developer shall provide proof to the zoning administrator from the state secretary of state of the incorporation of the subdivision's homeowners' association and proof that said association holds title to the right-of-way of the streets on behalf of the purchasers and requires all purchasers of lots in said subdivision to be members of said homeowners' association; g. Place at the entrance to said subdivision a sign, approved by the zoning administrator, indicating that the streets in the subdivision are private streets; h. If a gate or other controlled access is installed at the entrance to the subdivision, a place which provides emergency access to the subdivision by emergency agencies must first be approved by the emergency agencies of the county. Access must also be provided to anyone providing utilities to said subdivision; and i. All agreements, restrictive covenants and other documentation related to the development shall be furnished to and approved by the zoning administrator, prior to commencement of development. (Ord. of 12-7-2004, art. VI, § 6.7) Sec. 50-12. - Required improvements. Prior to consideration by the county for the final approval of any subdivision, manufactured house park, or residential or commercial development, the following private or public improvements, facilities, and utilities shall be fully planned and their completion guaranteed by the developer's providing the county with a payment and performance bond, an irrevocable letter of credit, or by the full payment of the cost of those improvements. The full cost of all submissions required for approval and all required improvements shall be borne entirely by the owner/developer. (1) General. a. An outline survey and site development plan, prepared and signed by an engineer, architect, or surveyor licensed by the state, together with a certificate of approval from the county health department shall accompany the application for approval submitted to the zoning administrator for review. An application review fee in an amount determined and approved by the county shall be paid together with the application. b. The developer shall submit the names of streets for approval by the county certifying that the proposed names are not confusingly similar to other existing named streets. The decision of the zoning administrator approving or disapproving the proposed names shall be final. c. The developer shall comply with chapter 16, article VI of this Code and guidelines set forth in the latest edition of the Georgia Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control. The location of the erosion control devices may have to be altered from that shown on the approved plans due to changes in drainage patterns created during construction. It is the developer's responsibility to accomplish erosion control for all drainage patterns created at various stages during construction. Any difficulty in controlling erosion during any phase of construction shall be immediately reported to the county. Failure to properly install, operate, or maintain all erosion control measures may result in all site activity being stopped until such measures are corrected to the satisfaction of the county. d.
